(2) RC WO qualification and development.
(a) MOS qualification.
1. Basic level MOS qualification.
a. Newly accessed WOs who have not successfully completed a pre-commissioning course will attend an accredited
Warrant Officer Candidate School (WOCS), or an accredited Regional Training Institute (RTI). Upon course completion, the candidate is eligible for appointment to the grade of WO1, but is not yet MOS-qualified.
b. Upon completion of an accredited pre-commissioning course newly appointed WOs must complete an accredited
proponent MOS WOBC to continue serving in the Army as a WO. WO1 appointments are contingent upon successfully completing WOBC. WOBC requires completion within two years of appointment or an exception to policy is
requested and approved, otherwise, the WO will be discharged from the Service. This course is a requirement for
promotion to CW2. Upon successful completion of WOBC, the WO is awarded a Signal MOS and given an initial
operational assignment.
2. Advanced level MOS qualification. WOs must attend and complete a proponent accredited WOAC. USAR WOs
must successful complete WOAC for promotion to CW3.
3. Senior level MOS qualification. WOs must attend and complete a proponent accredited WOSC. USAR WOs must
successful complete WOSC for promotion to CW4.
4. Master level MOS qualification. Following selection for promotion to CW5, WOs must attend and complete the
Warrant Officer Senior Staff Course (WOSSC). USAR WOs must successful complete WOSSC for promotion to CW4.
(b) Professional development. RC WOs professional development goals are outlined in paragraph 22–3b(1)(b).
(c) Qualification and assignment.
1. WO1/CW2. Basic level, tactical, and technical experts who should expect to serve in brigade level positions, see
paragraph 22–4b(2)(b) for MOS 250N network management technician; paragraph 22–4b(3)(b) for MOS 251A information systems technician, and paragraph 22–4b(4)(b) for MOS 254A Signal systems support technicians.
2. CW3. Advanced level, tactical, and technical experts who should expect to serve in division level positions, see
paragraph 22–4b(2)(c) for MOS 250N network management technician; paragraph 22–4b(3)(c) for MOS 251A information systems technician, and paragraph 22–4b(4)(c) for MOS 254A Signal systems support technicians.
3. CW4. Senior level, tactical and technical experts who should expect to serve in corps/echelons above corps level
positions, see paragraph 22–4b(2)(d) for MOS 250N network management technician; paragraph 22–4b(3)(d) for MOS
251A information systems technician, and paragraph 22–4b(4)(d) for MOS 254A Signal systems support technicians.
4. CW5. Master level, tactical, and technical experts who should expect to serve in echelon above corps/theatre level
positions, see paragraph 22–4b(5)(b) for MOS 255Z Senior signal systems technicians. RC Soldiers should not rotate
into NGB positions and visa versa. They are constrained by TPU/retirement requirements, and must spend a certain
number of years in the component for retirement eligibility. Soldiers must remain aware of regulations pertaining to
transfers and their retirement requirements.

Chapter 23
Telecommunication Systems Engineering Functional Area
23–1. Unique features of the Telecommunication Systems Engineering functional area
a. Unique purpose of the Telecommunication Systems Engineering FA. Telecommunications Systems Engineering
(FA 24) is a FA within the network and space operations group of the operations support functional category. FA 24
provides the Army with a core of professional telecommunications systems engineers, who engineer, design, develop,
install, implement, integrate, test, accept, and upgrade tactical, strategic, and sustaining base wired and wireless
telecommunications systems and networks enterprise-wide at all levels of the GIG (terrestrial, air, and satellite) in
support of Army, Joint, interagency, and multinational operations worldwide. The FA 24 proponent office is located at
the U.S. Army Signal Center, Fort Gordon, Georgia.
b. Unique functions performed by the Telecommunication Systems Engineering FA. FA 24 officers perform the
following critical tasks in Army and JIIM units and environments:
(1) Engineer telecommunications systems into an integrated network.
(2) Engineer network security architectures.
(3) Assess a telecommunications network or network design plan.
(4) Validate a telecommunications network or network design plan.
(5) Conduct current network operations.

214

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

(6) Plan future network operations.
(7) Manage a network and services design project.
(8) Prepare technical specifications documentation.
(9) Manage information technology contracts.
(10) Evaluate telecommunications technologies.
c. Unique features of work in the Telecommunication Systems Engineering FA. Work within FA 24 requires the
application of technical skills to plan, design, and install telecommunications systems and networks using existing and
future military and commercial off-the-shelf (COTS) telecommunications systems and equipment. FA 24 officers
operate enterprise-wide, interfacing with and understanding the roles of Signal (Branch 25) and information systems
management (FA 53) officers in order to provide seamless, robust, and reliable communications and information
services to the warfighter.
d. Areas of concentration (AOC) in the Telecommunication Systems Engineering. There is one AOC 24A, Telecommunication Systems Engineering.
23–2. Officer characteristics required
Telecommunications Systems Engineering officers must have a Top Secret clearance with special compartmented
information access. FA 24 officers should initiate procedures to obtain the proper level of clearance immediately upon
notification of the FA 24 functional designation. Additionally, there are FA unique skills, knowledge, and abilities.
a. Desired officer background. Officers should possess an undergraduate or graduate degree in one of the following
disciplines:
(1) Electrical engineering.
(2) Telecommunication systems engineering.
(3) Telecommunication engineering.
(4) Telecommunications management.
(5) Information systems engineering.
(6) Computer systems engineering.
(7) Engineering.
(8) Computer science.
(9) Math.
(10) Physics.
b. Unique skills.
(1) Conceptual competence. FA 24 officers must possess the ability to synthesize information and to clearly
communicate information required to make timely decisions. The uncertain conditions of military operations will
demand mental endurance and agility, often under severe conditions and time constraints. FA 24 officers must
effectively develop and communicate their vision, purpose, and direction.
(2) Interpersonal competence. FA 24 officers are part of a network operations team. They are skilled in building
teamwork within their organization and recognize that they often simultaneously belong to many teams. They must
possess the ability to express themselves to their senior leaders and subordinate clearly, concisely, and accurately, both
orally and in writing.
(3) Technical competence. FA 24 officers must possess the necessary expertise to provide a seamless, secure, global
network that enables information superiority for the warfighter. FA 24 officers must leverage their system engineering
experience to assist in the development of the LandWarNet. They prepare and present clear and informative briefings
relating to their technical areas of expertise to their peers, subordinates and superiors.
(4) Tactical competence. FA 24 officers must show proficiency in required professional knowledge, judgment, and
warfighting. They must apply their doctrinal knowledge and understanding to the solution of tactical problems and
formulate and defend solutions to problems using current Army and Joint doctrine. These skills are gained and
developed through operational assignments and continuous professional study and self-development.
(5) Decisionmaking skills. FA 24 officers often work in an environment where sound and timely decisions are made
while time available for problem analysis is seriously constrained. Information gained in this environment will vary in
its completeness and ambiguity. An ability to operate under stress and make decisions is critical to success.
c. Unique knowledge. The components of network operations (NETOPS) consist of enterprise systems management/
network management, computer network defense/information assurance, and content staging/information dissemination
management). These components comprise the core competencies of the Signal Regiment and all Signal Regiment
officers must possess knowledge of all three. Additionally, FA 24 officers are responsible for maintaining specific
proficiency in the following:
(1) Know the underlying theory and concepts of telecommunications transmission technologies.
(2) Know current commercial, JIIM telecommunications systems, their employment, capabilities, interoperability,
and limitations.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

215

(3) Know current telecommunications regulations, policies and procedures as implemented by international agreement, Federal law, national policy, and DOD and Army regulations.
(4) Know integrated life cycle support plans for fielded telecommunications systems.
(5) Know and implement national, DOD, and Army policy for the protection and security of command and control
(C2) telecommunications.
(6) Know and apply the fault, configuration, accounting, performance and, security (FCAPS) management model of
telecommunications network management
(7) Know end-to-end analysis and engineering of telecommunications systems.
(8) Know technical frameworks for the test, evaluation, implementation, and validation of interoperable-telecommunications systems.
23–3. Officer development and assignments
a. FA development. Officers are functionally designated into FA 24 at their 7th YOS to reset the future field grade
officer inventory by anticipating future branch and functional officer requirements. Limited functional designation at
the 4th YOS will occur to fill operational requirements for specific FAs at the rank of captain. Officers interested in
functional designation as an FA 24 should visit the AHRC Web site via AKO and follow the FA 24 link. The FA 24
personnel proponent, in conjunction with the FA 24 assignments officer, will actively recruit quality captains to fill FA
24 requirements.
b. FA assignments. All FA 24 positions are considered FA developmental positions. As officers progress through
their careers, they are afforded a variety of FA assignments and Army unique training and educational opportunities
based on their performance of duties, educational background, and the needs of the Army. Captain.
(1) Captain.
(a) Officers generally attend the CCC at about their 4th year of commissioned Service in preparation for company
grade duties and responsibilities. Captains who are functionally designated at their 4th YOS will more than likely attend
the Signal CCC in conjunction with the Telecommunications Systems Engineering Course (TSEC). Those captains who
are functionally designated at their 7th YOS more than likely have already attended a CCC and thus, will only attend
TSEC. Special training necessary to support an officer’s follow-on assignment is scheduled after completing CCC.
(b) After completion of TSEC, captains are normally assigned to positions that will enable them to gain experience
and develop technical and tactical competence. Captains should aggressively prepare for and seek assignments that will
develop competencies as a network or system engineer. Officers should expect to serve in progressive positions to
develop leadership, FA skills, and complement this with experience at a level of division or higher.
(c) At the rank of captain, it is expected that assignments will give an FA 24 competencies in network engineering,
assessment, managing, and planning, as well as experience in conducting current network operations. Moreover,
assignments will allow captains to gain knowledge, skills, and abilities in accurately evaluating technologies and
preparing technical specification documents based on those evaluations. Typical developmental assignments include—
1. Network engineer in division G–6
2. Systems engineer in a Signal battalion/brigade/command.
3. Systems engineer at JIIM staff level.
4. Project manager at JIIM staff level.
5. Telecommunications test, evaluation, and integration officer.
(2) Major.
(a) Telecommunication Systems Engineering officers will attend the 14–week resident ILE common core course not
later than the completion of their 12th year of commissioned Service. ILE education for all FA 24 officers is essential
to their professional development. Officers completing the ILE curriculum and TSEC are ILE and Joint professional
military education (JPME 1) qualified. The TSEC is the second phase of ILE, although an FA 24 more than likely will
have already graduated from TSEC prior to attending ILE.
(b) Majors must exercise continuous self-development efforts to fully master all aspects of telecommunications
systems engineering to include Joint and multinational operations. Self-development may include correspondence
courses, civilian education, and institutional training. Officers must devote time to a professional reading program in
order to broaden their tactical and technical perspective; they should also conduct research and write articles for
professional, military publications. Skills and experience will drive an officer’s career path and future assignments.
Completion of ILE and successful Service in desirable positions of responsibility will best prepare majors for
promotion to lieutenant colonel. The optimal time line to provide officers with the opportunity to successfully serve in
positions that will develop the competencies gained at the rank of major is 18–36 months.
(c) At the rank of major, it is expected that assignments will give a Telecommunications Systems Engineer
competencies in validating telecommunication networks and network design plans. Assignments will additionally
enable majors to enhance competencies in planning, engineering, and assessing a network in support of future
operations. Moreover, majors will gain knowledge, skills, and abilities in managing network and services design
projects. Typical developmental assignments include—

216

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

1. Network engineer in division G–6.
2. Systems engineer in a Signal battalion/brigade/command.
3. Systems engineer/plans officer in JIIM staff-level.
4. Telecommunications Systems Engineer, TNOSC Network Management Division.
5. Project manager in JIIM staff-level.
6. Deputy Director, Theater Network Operations & Security Center (TNOSC).
7. Telecommunications test, evaluation, and integration officer.
8. Information assurance officer at JIIM staff-level.
9. Radio frequency engineer officer at JIIM staff-level.
(3) Lieutenant colonel.
(a) Officers selected for lieutenant colonel should seek assignments of greater responsibility in FA positions. The
objective in lieutenant colonel assignments is to give officers the opportunity to enhance competencies and make a
greater contribution to the telecommunications systems engineering community for the Army.
(b) The majority of FA 24 lieutenant colonels should concentrate on seeking out and performing well in critical staff
positions at the Army level as well as in different JIIM environments. Lieutenant colonels benefit by having an
advanced degree and also gain an advantage by being selected for and attending a SSC or completing the AWC
Distance Education Course.
(c) At the rank of lieutenant colonel, developmental assignments will enable individuals to enhance competencies in
planning, engineering, assessing, and validating Army, JIIM strategic networks in support of current and future
operations. Additionally, lieutenant colonels will enhance their competencies of testing, evaluation, and documenting of
technical specifications. Moreover, lieutenant colonels will acquire competencies of managing information technology
(IT) contracts in support of IT projects. Typical developmental assignments include—
1. Director, TNOSC.
2. Deputy Director at Battle Command Battle Lab.
3. Chief, ACERT.
4. Systems engineer at JIIM staff-level.
5. Integration/interoperability officer at JIIM staff-level.
6. C4I staff officer/plans officer at JIIM staff-level.
7. Chief, Materiel Requirements Division, Combat Developments Directorate, SIGCEN.
8. Chief information officer/chief technology officer at JIIM staff-level.
9. Chief, Spectrum Management IT Division, Joint Spectrum Center (JSC).
(4) Colonel.
(a) Attendance at a SSC or completion of AWC Distance Education Course is advantageous and selective. Except
through an established resident program such as the AWC, the Industrial College of the Armed Forces (ICAF), and
similar senior Service courses, completion of the nonresident course is the only other means by which an Army officer
can receive credit for SSC training. However, once selected and enrolled in the nonresident course, an officer is no
longer eligible to attend a resident SSC. Therefore, it is recommended that the officer discuss this with his or her
assignment manager prior to applying for the correspondence course. The SSC selection board is responsible for
selection of all Active Duty officers for participation in the AWC Distance Education Course.
(b) Colonels should strive to hold leadership positions at the Army and Joint levels as well as in different JIIM
environments. Colonels may also serve in branch/FA generalist positions that contribute to their professional development, but are not specifically related to their AOC. Criteria for selection include overall manner of performance,
military experience, military and civilian education, and demonstrated potential to serve in positions of increased
responsibility. FA 24 officers are encouraged to seek Joint duty assignments and multinational forces assignments.
These assignments are viewed as key for career enhancement.
(c) Developmental assignments at the rank of colonel will enable a senior FA 24 to continue to enhance competencies in planning, engineering, assessing, and validating Army, JIIM strategic networks in support of current and
future operations. Additionally, colonels will continue to enhance their competencies of testing, evaluation, and
documenting of technical specifications. Lastly, colonels will continue to enhance competencies of managing IT
contracts in support of IT projects. Typical developmental assignments include—
1. Director/deputy director/chief at HQDA, JIIM level.
2. Director, JSC.
3. Director, ANOSC.
4. Director, Battle Command Battle Lab, Fort Gordon, Georgia.
5. Technical advisor for an acquisition program executive office.
c. Joint assignments. Many FA 24 field grade positions are on the DOD Joint duty assignment list (JDAL). Officers
assigned to JDAL billets may attend JPME II and are designated as a Joint specialty officer (skill identifier 3L) upon
successful tour completion. Telecommunications Systems Engineers are not generally considered for Joint duty
assignments until selected for major. Even though Joint experience is important to the Army and to individual officers
DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

217

for advancement into senior leadership positions, not all FA 24s will receive Joint assignments. This will not preclude
their selection to the grade of colonel.
23–4. Assignment preferences and precedence
The assignment sequencing in a FA is not as rigid as that of a branch. An objective of professional development for
FA 24 officers is to expose them to a variety of environments in which telecommunication systems engineering is
performed. After receiving initial training, FA 24 officers should seek different types of jobs within the FA 24 structure
to provide breadth to their experiences.
a. Preferences. FA 24s have diverse opportunities, which allow for numerous career development paths. Individuals
should base their preferences on ensuring a variety of full spectrum operations at all levels of Army and Joint
organizations and in different JIIM environments. The goal of FA 24 professional development is to produce officers
skilled in planning, engineering, validating, and assessing telecommunication systems. Officers will attend the TSEC
prior to initial assignment to an FA 24 position. By exception, officers are also assigned to an assignment prior to
completion of TSEC to meet real-world mission requirements.
b. Precedence. Assignment to developmental FA positions will have precedence, although there is flexibility on the
sequence of assignments. Some FA 24 billets are designated as requiring advanced civilian education, such as a
master’s degree. Officers assigned into those jobs must have completed the necessary courses of instruction. If
possible, FA 24 officers should complete an Army FA 24 assignment before an FA 24 assignment to a Joint command.
23–5. Duration of critical officer life cycle assignments
The objective under force stabilization rules for most FA 24 assignments is 36 months. Tours are possibly longer in
areas with a high concentration of billets such as the National Capital Region. OCONUS locations will continue to
require specific tour lengths. Because there are no positions that specifically qualify an FA 24 officer, completion of
ILE, the TSEC, and FA 24 assignment experience fully develops an officer in this FA. Figure 23–1, below, depicts
FA24 developmental assignments by grade.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

Figure 23–1. FA 24 Active Army Developmental Model

23–6. Requirements, authorizations, and inventory
a. Goal. The goal is to maintain a healthy, viable career path for FA 24 officers. To do this, the inventory is
optimized in order to fill FA authorization requirements and to provide FA 24 officers sufficient time for development
prior to consideration for promotion to lieutenant colonel and colonel. In order to enhance specialization and development, FA 24 officer participation in generalist (01A) assignments are minimized.
b. Officer Personnel Management System (OPMS) implementation. The number of FA 24 authorizations, by grade,
will vary as force structure decisions are made and actions to implement them are taken. Officers desiring more
information on current authorizations or inventory should contact either the FA 24 personnel proponent office or the
FA 24 assignments officer at AHRC.
23–7. Key officer life cycle initiatives for Telecommunication Systems Engineering
a. Structure. FA 24 officers serve at division echelons and above, to include JIIM environments. The chief of the
Signal Corps is the proponent for FA 24 and guides its development.
b. Acquire. FA 24 officers are accessed in the following ways:
(1) DA G–1 has approved changing functional designation from a single point at the 10th YOS to multiple
functional designation points: a limited designation at the 4th YOS and full designation at the 7th YOS. Officers
interested in being designated FA 24 can learn more by visiting the AHRC Web site via AKO.
(2) The FA 24 personnel proponent will actively recruit quality captains to fill FA 24 requirements. Officers

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

219

accessed in this manner are managed by both their basic branch and the FA, if given an assignment, and until the FDB
at the 4 or 7 year point in an officer’s career. Officers who serve in a FA24 position prior to functional designation are
not guaranteed functional designation as an FA 24. The pools of available officers identified in this manner are used to
select those officers who will receive training and an assignment in FA 24. This process replaces the Functional Area
Designation Board (FADB) that we utilized under OPMS 3. Officers will undergo a functional designation board at
their seven year mark in their career. This HQDA board will decide in which of the three functional categories each
officer is best suited to serve. Decisions are based on needs of the Army, the officer’s preference, rater and senior rater
recommendations, and the officer’s skills and training. The three functional categories are: maneuver, fires, and effects
(MF&E); operations support; and force sustainment. In addition, a limited number of officers may electively choose to
participate in a four year functional designation (done in the 3d YOS). This board is not mandatory nor is it open to all
FAs. After the board convenes, each officer will be assigned a branch or FA within one of the three functional
categories listed above. Officers who are selected to serve inside of FA24 will be then managed by their FA career
manager. Promotions to the next higher grade for the major, lieutenant colonel, and colonel board will be done
according to the functional category to which the officer belongs.
c. Distribute. The Operations Support Division, Officer Personnel Management Directorate (OPMD) at AHRC,
manages all officers serving in FA 24 assignments. Officers who complete an FA 24 assignment and are not
functionally designated as an FA 24 will return to the control of their basic branch manager at AHRC. All functionally
designated FA 24s (captain - lieutenant colonel) remain under the control of operations support. FA 24 colonels are
managed by the senior leaders development office (SLD).
d. Compensate. FA 24 officers receive the same pay, entitlements, and benefits as all other officers.
e. Deploy. Telecommunication Systems Engineering officers are warfighters who remain personally and professionally prepared to deploy worldwide at all times. Whether to TOE units with high levels of readiness or fixed site TDA
organizations, all FA 24 officers are deployable to accomplish missions across the full spectrum of operations.
Telecommunication Systems Engineers may deploy tomorrow with their units to deter potential adversaries and to
protect national interests; or as individuals to support Joint and multinational operations. FA 24 officers must prepare
themselves and their Families for the most challenging functional designation.
f. Sustain. All officers designated FA 24 will compete within their functional designation for promotion to major,
lieutenant colonel, and colonel. Officers who functionally designate into the operations support functional category as
FA 24s are eligible to change their regimental affiliation to the Signal Regiment. This can be accomplished through the
officer’s local military records officer or by contacting the FA 24 personnel proponent office.
g. Develop. FA 24 incorporates a professional officer development career plan offering significant opportunity for
schooling and assignments. As FA 24 officers progress through their careers, they should seek advanced military
schooling and education opportunities to stay abreast of the rapidly changing telecommunication technology field. FA
24 officers should diversify their assignments to broaden their operational experiences and increase their skills,
knowledge, and abilities in information technology. FA 24 officers are encouraged to complete professional training
and technical certification programs or obtain a license as a professional engineer related to telecommunication systems
engineering technology.
h. Training. FA 24 institutional training includes the following elements:
(1) Information Systems Operations Leveler Course (ISOL), Fort Gordon, GA.
(2) Telecommunications Systems Engineering Course (TSEC), Fort Gordon, GA.
(3) FA 24 senior captains and majors will attend the ILE common core in residence at a course location (CL) site.
Normally, the CL site for FA 24 is at Fort Gordon, GA. Upon completion of the common core course, FA 24 officers
are Intermediate Staff College (ISC) graduates. Full ILE credit is awarded an FA24 officer upon completion of the ILE
common core, the ISOL, and the TSEC and credentialed JPME I. The ILE common core can be taken before, after, or
in conjunction with the ISOL/TSEC course sequence. In select cases, an appropriate graduate degree program may take
the place of ISOL/TSEC for ILE credit. RC officers can attend The Army School System (TASS) classes located in
CONUS and OCONUS as well as CL sites.
(4) National Defense University (NDU) offers several professional development programs which apply to FA 24.
These include the Chief Information Officer (CIO) Certificate Program and the Information Assurance Certificate
Program.
(5) Civilian training and education programs below are available for FA 24 officers to enhance their skills within
their functional designation.
(6) Training with industry (TWI) is a work-experience program to provide an extensive exposure to managerial
techniques and industrial procedures within corporate America to competitively selected officers and NCOs. Training
received is normally not available either through the military school system or civilian university system. An officer is
assigned to a one-year tour with an approved industry partner, followed by a two year utilization assignment. FA 24
officers can apply for TWI by contacting their assignments officer at AHRC.
(7) Signal Regiment Graduate Education Program (SRGEP) and the U.S. Army Signal Center partners with civilian
universities to provide information technology related graduate degree programs for FA 24 officers. These programs

220

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

are available worldwide online. Selected graduate classes are also available in residence at Fort Gordon, GA. Interested
officers should contact the FA 24 proponent for more information.
(8) Information Assurance Scholarship Program (IASP) is a competitive, fully-funded scholarship program open to
officers and civilians throughout the DOD. Selected officers attend graduate school full-time and earn a master’s or
doctorate degree in the field of information assurance. Officers interested in this program should contact their
assignments officer at AHRC.
(9) FA 24 officers should pursue an aggressive self-development program throughout their careers that includes such
elements as industry certifications, academic certificates, professional licenses, and memberships in professional
organizations. Self-development information is obtained by visiting LandWarNet eUniversity via the AKO portal.
i. Separate. FA 24 officers separate from the Army in the same manner as all other officers.
23–8. Telecommunication Systems Engineering Reserve Component officers
a. General career development. Army National Guard (ARNG) and U.S. Army Reserve (USAR) Telecommunication Systems Engineering officers serve the same role and mission as their Active Army counterparts. The unique
nature of the RC Soldier’s role as a citizen Soldier poses a significant professional development challenge. To fulfill
their wartime mission of planning, engineering, and managing the integration of diverse telecommunication equipment
into interoperable systems and enterprise networks, Telecommunication Systems Engineering officers are dependent
upon extensive interaction between the Active Army and the RC. The quality of the Telecommunications Systems
Engineering officers in the RC is important to support this mission. For guidance on RC officer development, see
chapter 7. FA 24 has one AOC, 24A Telecommunications Systems Engineer.
b. FA qualification and development opportunities.
(1) FA 24 officers in the RC have challenging and complex missions. Inherent with these missions are specific
managerial and technical attributes for developing and employing telecommunications systems in both fixed and
mobile configurations. FA 24 officers are tactically and technically proficient and capable of understanding the scope
of a Telecommunications Systems Engineering officer’s duties. A requirement for proficiency in both peacetime and
wartime skills will provide significant educational and experiential challenges. Planned rotation into progressively
challenging FA 24 related positions, while considered essential to producing the best-qualified Telecommunications
Systems Engineering officer, are limited to geographical considerations.
(2) Geographic dispersion of Telecommunications Systems Engineer positions constrains RC career progression in
FA 24. Few RC FA 24 officers are afforded an opportunity to meet minimum career progression goals of the Active
Army. To meet professional development objectives, RC Telecommunication Systems Engineering officers are willing
to rotate between assignments with USAR TPU organizations, ARNG units and IMA positions. Usually there are
insufficient numbers of positions within a geographic area to continue in Telecommunication Systems Engineering FA
assignments. If geographic constraints are such that assignment to a Telecommunication Systems Engineering position
is not possible, officers should seek assignment in their basic branch or in a related FA required in the geographic
region.
(3) Telecommunication Systems Engineering officer assignments in the RC are almost split evenly between TOE
and TDA organizations. Their duties and responsibilities are fundamentally the same as their Active Army counterparts
except for those personnel management, administrative, and operational requirements unique to the ARNG and USAR.
(4) Officers are assigned to the IRR when unable to accept a TPU or ARNG unit assignment. Officers in the IRR
may request assignment to a RTU, IMA position, a tour of ADSW, AT, or ADT. Officers in the IRR may meet
professional military education (PME) requirements by requesting ADT. All RC officers, major and below with less
than 15 years of active Federal Service (AFS), may request AGR assignment.
(5) RC FA 24 authorizations will vary as force structure decisions are made and actions to implement them are
taken. USAR officers desiring more information on current authorizations or positions may contact the Combined FA
Management Office (CFAMO) at the AHRC–St. Louis, Missouri. ARNG officers desiring more information on current
authorizations or positions may contact the ARNG personnel office of the state or territory in which they reside.
(6) RC officers (captain and above) who acquire telecommunication systems engineering skills, knowledge, and
attributes in a civilian workplace or through education and training may apply for constructive credit to award FA 24.
Awarding constructive credit is based on documented experience in telecommunications systems engineering; professional certifications, advanced degrees, and civilian workplace experience. Candidates should submit requests for
constructive credit with supporting documents through their USAR or ARNG component chain of command to
Commander, USASC&FG, Office Chief of Signal, ATTN: ATZH–POO, Fort Gordon, Georgia 30905. Supporting
documents include (as applicable)—
(a) Cover letter outlining qualifications.
(b) Resume.
(c) DA Form 2–1/officer record brief (ORB) or biographical record brief (BRB).
(d) Transcripts (graduate and/or undergraduate).
(e) OERs/civilian job evaluations.
(f) Civilian training certificates.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

221

(g) Industry certification certificates (MCSE, MCP, CCNA, and so on).
(h) Letter(s) of recommendation.
c. Professional development. There are four phases of professional development for RC Telecommunication Systems
Engineering officers. The phases relate to military rank and include broadly based goals and career objectives at each
rank so that an officer may expand capabilities and optimize performance. Telecommunication Systems Engineering
life cycle development objectives, RC requirements, and an officer’s own strengths, priorities, civilian experience,
private and Service provided education, and performance influence their professional development. FA qualification
standards by grade, along with typical RC duty positions are as follows:
(1) Captain.
(a) For 24A qualification as well as consideration for promotion to major, Telecommunications Systems Engineer
officers should have a hard skill undergraduate degree in one of the following:
1. Electrical engineering (communications).
2. Telecommunication systems engineering.
3. Telecommunication engineering.
4. Telecommunications management.
5. Information systems engineering.
6. Computer systems engineering.
7. Engineering.
8. Computer science.
9. Math.
(b) Officers must complete the ISOL (ATRRS Course Number 7E–F70) followed by the TSEC (ATRRS Course
Number 4C–24A) for initial qualification as a FA 24. Attendance at the ISOL is waived based on prior equivalent
education/experience. Typical TOE positions include communications-electronics engineer, systems engineer, and
communications-electronics staff officer. Typical TDA positions include Signal support officer, systems engineer, and
communications-electronics staff officer.
(2) Major. The primary professional development objective of a Telecommunication Systems Engineering major in
the RC is to continue to strengthen telecommunication systems engineering skills. During this phase, officers must
enroll in and complete ILE common core or its equivalent (50 percent completion required for promotion to lieutenant
colonel). Selected RC officers may attend the ILE common core course at a CL site such as Fort Gordon, GA. FA 24
majors are highly encouraged to pursue a specialty related graduate degree and obtain a professional engineering
license. Telecommunication systems engineering majors should serve a minimum of 24 months cumulative Service in a
Telecommunication Systems Engineering operations or operational support major position.
(3) Lieutenant colonel. Lieutenant colonels can expect assignments to senior staff positions employing them in a
variety of diverse and challenging FA related positions. FA 24 officers should seek PME at the SSC level. Telecommunication Systems Engineering RC lieutenant colonels are eligible for selection to the rank of colonel upon completion
of the requisite Service requirements listed in chapter 7 of this pamphlet. Lieutenant colonels remain eligible for
promotion as long as they continue to serve in an active status and meet selection criteria. FA 24 lieutenant colonels
should serve a minimum of 48 months cumulative Service in a Telecommunication Systems Engineering support
position.
(4) Colonel. The primary objective for officers during this phase is maximum use of the officer’s technical and
tactical capabilities, managerial skills, and executive skills in positions of higher responsibility. RC Telecommunication
Systems Engineering colonels should serve a minimum 72 months cumulative Service in an FA 24 operations or
operational support position.

Chapter 24
Information Systems Management Functional Area
24–1. Unique features of the Information Systems Management functional area
a. Unique purpose of the Information Systems Management FA. Information Systems Management (FA 53) is a FA
is in the network and space operations grouping of the operations support functional category. Information System
Managers integrate diverse forms of enterprise services such as configuration management, active directory, database
management, e-mail, and Web portals that must operate seamlessly in support of the Army and JIIM operations
worldwide. FA 53 officers supply their expertise of all enterprise systems technologies, along with their knowledge of
highly technical concepts, in order to provide the warfighter with the information required to make timely decisions on
the battlefield. The FA 53 proponent office is located at the U.S. Army Signal Center, Fort Gordon, Georgia.
b. Unique functions performed by the Information Systems Management FA. FA 53 officers perform the following
critical tasks for Army and Joint units as well as in units in the other JIIM environments:
(1) Information dissemination management.
(a) Write the IT portion of an operations plan (OPLAN), an operations order (OPORD), or a fragmentary order
(FRAGO)
(b) Perform system analysis with user.
(c) Implement IT training plan.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

223

(d) Develop incident response procedures.
(e) Develop IT training plan.
(f) Develop Web-based applications.
(g) Manage Web-based applications.
(h) Manage a database management system (DBMS).
(i) Assist in the Configuration Information Management Board (CIMB).
(j) Maintain an IT training plan.
(k) Assist in the integration of knowledge management systems.
(l) Develop security in a local area network (LAN) Architecture.
(m) Manage the implementation of an automated information system (AIS).
(2) Information assurance.
(a) Implement security in local area network (LAN) architecture.
(b) Maintain security in local area network (LAN) architecture.
(c) Develop a continuity of operations plan (COOP).
(d) Direct the installation and configuration of firewalls and other network security systems.
(e) Maintain firewalls and other network security systems.
(f) Perform DOD IT security certification and accreditation process (DITSCAP).
(g) Develop incident response procedures.
(h) Develop IT standing operating procedures (SOPs).
(i) Integrate IT system with allied, host nation (HN), Joint, and non-Governmental agencies.
(j) Develop security in local area network (LAN) architecture.
(3) NETOPS.
(a) Conduct a site survey.
(b) Maintain a local area network (LAN).
(c) Develop life cycle management plan for IT assets.
(d) Implement life cycle management plan for IT assets.
(e) Manage life cycle management plan for IT assets.
(f) Manage standard army management information systems (STAMIS).
(g) Obtain IT services.
(h) Manage IT services.
(i) Implement a local area network (LAN).
(j) Develop a local area network (LAN).
(k) Integrate a local area network (LAN) with a wide area network (WAN).
(l) Maintain a local area network (LAN) with a wide area network (WAN).
(m) Develop the Server Configuration Plan.
(n) Implement the Server Configuration Plan.
(o) Maintain the configuration of servers.
c. Unique features of work in the Information Systems Management FA. Work within FA 53 requires the application
of technical skills to plan, design, and install information systems and services using existing and future military and
COTS information systems and equipment. FA 53 officers operate enterprise-wide within an information systems team,
to include interfacing with and understanding the roles of the Signal officer (Branch 25) and Telecommunication
Systems Engineering (FA 24) officer to provide seamless, enterprise-wide information systems in support of the
warfighter.
d. AOC in the Information Systems Management. There is one AOC 53A, Information Systems Management.
24–2. Officer characteristics required
a. Desired officer background. It is recommended that officers possess an undergraduate or graduate degree in one
of the following disciplines:
(1) Information systems management.
(2) Computer systems management.
(3) Computer science.
(4) Computer engineering.
(5) Computer systems engineering.
(6) Information technology.
(7) Computer information systems.
(8) Computer resource and information management.
(9) Technology management.

224

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

b. Unique skills.
(1) Conceptual competence. FA 53 officers must possess the ability to synthesize information and to clearly
communicate information required to make timely decisions. The uncertain conditions of military operations will
demand mental endurance and agility, often under severe conditions and time constraints. FA 53 officers must
effectively develop and communicate their vision, purpose, and direction.
(2) Interpersonal competence. FA 53 officers are part of a network operations team. They are skilled in building
teamwork within their organization and recognize that they often simultaneously belong to many teams. They must
possess the ability to express themselves to their team members clearly, concisely, and accurately, both orally and in
writing.
(3) Technical competence. FA 53 officers must possess the necessary expertise to accomplish all tasks and functions
of the FA. They are able to apply their technical knowledge and skills to solve problems associated with network. They
are able to prepare and present clear and informative briefings relating to their technical areas of expertise to their
peers, subordinates, and superiors.
(4) Tactical competence. FA 53 officers must show proficiency in required professional knowledge, judgment, and
warfighting. They must apply their doctrinal knowledge and understanding to the solution of tactical problems and
formulate and defend solutions to problems using current Army and Joint doctrine.
(5) Decisionmaking skills. FA 53 officers often work in an environment where sound and timely decisions are made
while time available for problem analysis is seriously constrained. Information gained in this environment will vary in
its completeness and ambiguity. An ability to operate under stress and make decisions is critical to success.
(6) Tactical and technical skills. FA 53 officers are warfighters who are technically proficient with information
systems and network management tools. FA 53 mission success requires that officers understand the capabilities the
network offers and can leverage their capabilities to enhance unit proficiency. FA 53 officers must leverage their
network experience to assist in the development of the LandWarNet. These skills are gained and developed through
operational assignments and continuous professional study and self-development.
c. Unique knowledge. FA 53 officers are responsible for maintaining proficiency in the information system management discipline due to the rapid change of technology and operational concepts. They also understand—
(1) The tenets of enterprise system management/network management, information assurance/computer network
defense, and information dissemination management/content staging.
(2) Emerging COTS technologies and design methodologies for possible adaptation to military purposes.
(3) The capabilities and limitations of full spectrum operations tactical, theater, and strategic information systems.
(4) The interfaces of JIIM information systems.
(5) Information management responsibilities, policies, procedures, and regulations as detailed in Federal law, DOD,
and Army regulations.
(6) How to manage information systems facilities.
(7) The requirements for documenting support for information management.
(8) How to implement information assurance requirements to include defense-in-depth strategies.
(9) Fault management, configuration management, accounting/administration, performance management, and security management (FCAPS) concepts and principles.
(10) Total cost of ownership.
(11) Quality of service and assurance.
24–3. Officer development and assignments
a. Officers are functionally designated into FA 53 at their 7th YOS to reset the field grade inventory by anticipating
future branch and functional officer requirements. Limited FD at the 4th YOS will occur to fill operational requirements
for specific FAs at the rank of captain. Officers interested in functional designation as an FA 53 should visit the AHRC
Web site via Army Knowledge On-line and follow the FA 53 link. The FA 53 personnel proponent in conjunction with
the FA 53 assignments officer will actively recruit quality captains to fill FA 53 requirements.
b. All FA 53 positions are considered FA KD positions. As officers progress through their careers, they are afforded
a variety of FA assignments and Army unique training and educational opportunities based on their performance of
duties, educational background, and the needs of the Army. FA 53 officers receive training in any of the following
methods:
(1) Primary means of FA 53 training. Officers are trained as an FA 53 by completing the Information Systems
Operations Leveler (ISOL) Course followed by the Information Systems Management (ISM) Course.
(2) Alternate means of FA training. Officers who complete a graduate or Ph.D. degree either through the fullyfunded advanced civil schooling (ACS) program or through other means are considered initially qualified in FA 53.
Non-branch 25 officers are required to attend the ISOL upon graduation from an FA 53 directed ACS assignment. The
graduate degree must align with computer science, information technology, information systems management, or
related disciplines.
(3) FA 53 officers. Selected FA 53 officers may complete graduate school or other civilian training opportunities to

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

225

prepare them for FA 53 assignments requiring additional skills. All officers are encouraged to pursue a specialty related
graduate degree or specialty related industry certification program.
c. Once an officer is FD FA 53, development and training by rank is designed to increase officer’s technical and
tactical competencies through the officer education system (OES) and through breadth and depth of assignment.
(1) Captain. Developmental assignments will enable captains to acquire network management, information assurance, and information dissemination management competencies in support of an immediate headquarters. After
acceptance and approval for FA 53, captains are assigned to developmental and utilization tours in an FA 53 coded
position after completing KD jobs in their basic branch. FA 53 captains are encouraged to pursue development and
utilization in Information Systems Management to gain training and experience prior to functional designation at 7th
YOS. Captains accessed and who are released by their basic branch will receive their FA 53 training primarily by
attending the ISOL Course followed by the ISM Course. Some captains are selected for fully-funded ACS or TWI with
a follow-on utilization assignment in an Army Education Requirements Systems (AERS) coded position. Typical
developmental assignments include:
(a) Information Systems Management officer in a brigade/BCT/SBCT S–6.
(b) Information Systems Management officer in Signal brigade/command.
(c) Information Systems Management officer in a division G–6.
(d) Information Systems Management officer in a support battalion.
(e) Information Systems Management officer in NETCOM.
(f) Information Systems Management officer in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
(g) Information Systems Management officer at Army or Joint staffs.
(h) Information assurance officer at Army or JIIM staffs or in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
(2) Major. Developmental assignments will allow majors to enhance competencies to implement and maintain local
area networks, develop and plan information technology architectures, and implement information assurance concepts
and principles. Additionally, majors will acquire competency in performing system analysis, developing response
procedures, performing accreditation processes, and integrating IT systems in all JIIM environments. Typical developmental assignments include—
(a) Information Systems Management officer in division G–6.
(b) Information Systems Management officer in Signal brigade/command.
(c) Information Systems Management officer in support brigade.
(d) Information assurance manager, division G–6.
(e) Information Systems Management officer in NETCOM.
(f) Information Systems Management officer/C4I systems officer at Army or Joint staffs or in organizational staffs
in all JIIM environments.
(g) Computer systems analyst at Army or JIIM staffs or in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
(h) Network plans officer/security officer/manager in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
(3) Lieutenant colonel. Lieutenant colonels are generally assigned to senior staff positions of increased responsibility
where they can fully use their knowledge of the Army and their information systems management experience. At this
grade, developmental assignments will enable lieutenant colonels to enhance competencies in developing and planning
information technology architectures, and implementing information assurance concepts and principles. Lieutenant
colonels will enhance competencies in performing system analysis, developing response procedures, performing
accreditation processes, and integrating IT systems with JIIM organizations. Typical developmental assignments at
lieutenant colonel include—
(a) Information Systems Management officer at Army or Joint staffs or in organizational staffs in all JIIM
environments.
(b) Information Systems Management officer in support command.
(c) Director/Chief in Signal brigade/command.
(d) Director/Chief at Army or Joint staffs, or in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
(e) Deputy, CIO/chief technical officer (CTO).
(f) Network plans officer/security officer/manager at Army or Joint staffs or in organizational staffs in all JIIM
environments.
(g) Information assurance officer at Army or Joint staffs or in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
(h) System analyst at Army or Joint staffs or in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
(4) Colonel. Colonels are generally assigned to senior staff positions of increased responsibility where they can fully
use their knowledge of the Army and their information systems management experience. At this grade, developmental
assignments will enable colonels to enhance competencies in developing and planning information technology architectures, and implementing information assurance concepts and principles. Colonels will enhance competencies in performing system analysis, developing response procedures, performing accreditation processes, and integrating IT systems
with organizations operating in the different JIIM environments. Typical developmental assignments at colonel
include—

226

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

(a) Deputy Chief of Staff for Information Management (DCSIM), sustaining base Active Army
(b) Director/Deputy/Chief at Army, JIIM staff level.
(c) Director, Leader College of Information Technology, SIGCEN.
(d) CIO/CTO at Army and Joint staffs or in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
(e) Plans/program developer at Army and Joint staffs or in organizational staffs in all JIIM environments.
d. Many FA 53 field grade positions are on the DOD JDAL. Officers assigned to JDAL billets may attend JPME II
and are designated as a Joint specialty officer (skill identifier 3L) upon successful tour completion. Information systems
managers are not generally considered for Joint duty assignments until selected for major. Even though Joint experience is important to the Army and to individual officers for advancement into senior leadership positions, not all FA
53s will receive Joint assignments. This will not preclude their selection to the grade of colonel.
24–4. Assignment preferences and precedence
The assignment sequencing in a FA is not as rigid as that of a branch. An objective of professional development for
FA 53 officers is to expose them to a variety of environments in which information systems management is performed.
After receiving initial training, FA 53 officers should seek different types of jobs within the FA 53 structure to provide
breadth to their experiences.
a. Preferences. FA 53 has diverse opportunities, which allow for numerous career development paths. The goal of
FA 53 professional development is to produce officers skilled in leading Soldiers both tactically and technically and
managing the integration of diverse forms of enterprise services. Officers will attend the ISM Course prior to initial
assignment to an FA 53 position. By exception, officers are assigned to an assignment prior to completion of ISM to
meet real-world mission requirements.
b. Precedence. Assignment to developmental FA positions will have precedence, although there is flexibility on the
sequence of assignments. Some FA 53 billets are designated as requiring advanced civilian education, such as a
master’s degree. Officers assigned into those jobs require completion of the necessary courses of instruction. If
possible, FA 53 officers should complete an Army FA 53 assignment before an FA 53 assignment to a Joint command.
24–5. Duration of developmental officer life cycle assignments
The goal under force stabilization rules for most FA 53 assignments is 36 months. Tours are longer in areas with a
high concentration of FA 53 billets such as the National Capital Region. OCONUS locations will continue to require
specific tour lengths. Figure 24–1, below, depicts the FA qualification requirements and developmental assignments by
grade.

24–6. Requirements, authorizations, and inventory
a. Goal. The goal is to maintain a healthy, viable career path for FA 53 officers. To do this, the inventory is
optimized in order to fill FA authorization requirements and to provide FA 53 officers sufficient time for development
prior to consideration for promotion to lieutenant colonel and colonel. In order to enhance specialization and development, FA 53 officer participation in generalist (01A) assignments are minimized.
b. OPMS implementation. The number of FA 53 authorizations, by grade, will vary as force structure decisions are
made and actions to implement them are taken. Officers desiring more information on current authorizations or
inventory should contact either the FA 53 personnel proponent office or the FA 24 assignments officer at AHRC.
24–7. Key officer life cycle initiatives for Information Systems Management
a. Structure. FA 53 officers serve at division echelons and above, to include organizations in most JIIM environments. The chief of the Signal Corps is the proponent for FA 53 and guides its development
b. Acquire. FA 53 officers are accessed in the following ways:
(1) Officers are functionally designated into FA 53 at their 7th YOS. The full functional designation will occur at the
th
7 YOS and is used to reset the future field grade officer inventory by anticipating future branch and functional officer
requirements. Limited functional designation at the 4th YOS will occur when required to fill operational requirements
for specific FAs at the rank of captain. Officers interested in designation as an FA 53 should visit AHRC via the AKO

228

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

portal and follow the FA 53 link. The FA 53 personnel proponent in conjunction with the FA 53 assignments officer
will actively recruit quality captains to fill FA 53 requirements.
(2) The FA 53 Personnel Proponent will actively recruit quality captains to fill FA 53 requirements. Officers
accessed in this manner are dual tracked and are not guaranteed an assignment nor functional designation as an FA 53.
The officers identified in this manner are used to select officers who will receive training and an assignment in FA 53.
This process replaces the FADB.
c. Distribute. The Operations Support Division, Officer Personnel Management Directorate (OPMD) at AHRC,
manages all officers serving in FA 53 assignments. Officers who complete an FA 53 assignment and are not
functionally designated as an FA 53 will return to the control of their basic branch manager at AHRC. All FD FA 53s
(captain - lieutenant colonel) remain under the control of OS. FA 53 colonels are managed by the SLD office.
d. Compensate. FA 53 officers receive the same pay, entitlements, and benefits as all other officers.
e. Deploy. Information Systems Management officers are warfighters who remain personally and professionally
prepared to deploy worldwide at all times. Whether to TOE units with high levels of readiness or fixed site TDA
organizations, all FA 53 officers are deployable to accomplish missions across the full spectrum of operations.
Information systems managers may deploy tomorrow with their units to deter potential adversaries and to protect
national interests or as individuals to support Joint and multinational operations. FA 53 officers must prepare
themselves and their Families for the most challenging functional designation.
f. Sustain. All officers designated FA 53 will compete within their functional designation for promotion to major,
lieutenant colonel, and colonel. Officers who functionally designate as FA 53 are eligible to change their regimental
affiliation to the Signal Regiment. This is accomplished through the officer’s local military records officer or by
contacting the FA 53 personnel proponent office.
g. Develop. FA 53 incorporates a professional officer development career plan offering significant opportunity for
schooling and assignments. As FA 53 officers progress through their careers, they should seek advanced military
schooling and education opportunities to stay abreast of the rapidly changing information technology field. FA 53
officers should diversify their assignments to broaden their operational experiences and increase their skills, knowledge, and abilities in information technology. FA 53 officers are encouraged to complete professional training and
technical certification programs or obtain a license as a professional information systems manager or related information technology disciplines.
h. Training. FA 53 institutional training includes the following elements:
(1) ISOL Course, Fort Gordon, GA
(2) ISM Course, Fort Gordon, GA
(3) FA 53 senior captains and majors will attend the ILE common core at a CL site. Normally, the CL site for FA
53 is at Fort Gordon, GA. Upon completion of the common core course, FA 53 officers are Intermediate Staff College
(ISC) graduates. Full ILE credit is awarded an FA 53 officer upon completion of the ILE common core, the ISOL
Course, and the ISM Course, and credentialed JPME I. The ILE common core is taken before, after, or in conjunction
with the ISOL/ISM Course sequence. In select cases, an appropriate graduate degree program may take the place of
ISOL/ISM Course for ILE credit. RC officers can attend The Army School System (TASS) classes located in CONUS
and OCONUS as well as CL sites.
(4) NDU offers several professional development programs which apply to FA 53. These include the CIO Certificate
Program and the Information Assurance Certificate Program.
(5) Civilian and training education described in the programs below are available for FA 53 officers to enhance their
skills within their functional designation.
(6) TWI is a work-experience program to provide an extensive exposure to managerial techniques and industrial
procedures within corporate America to competitively selected officers and noncommissioned officers. Training received is normally not available either through the military school system or civilian university system. An officer is
assigned to a one-year tour with an approved industry partner, followed by a two year utilization assignment. FA 53
officers can apply for TWI by contacting their assignments officer at AHRC.
(7) The U.S. Army Signal Center partners with civilian universities to provide IT related graduate degree programs
for FA 53 officers. These programs are available worldwide online. Selected graduate classes are also available in
residence at Fort Gordon, GA. Interested officers should contact the FA 53 proponent for more information about the
Signal Regiment Graduate Education Program (SRGEP).
(8) The Information Assurance Scholarship Program (IASP) is a competitive, fully-funded scholarship program open
to officers and civilians throughout the DOD. Selected officers attend graduate school full-time and earn a master’s or
doctorate degree in the field of information assurance. Officers interested in this program should contact their
assignments officer at AHRC.
(9) FA 53 officers should pursue an aggressive self-development program throughout their careers that includes such
elements as industry certifications, academic certificates, professional licenses, and memberships in professional
organizations.
i. Separate. FA 53 officers separate from the Army in the same manner as all other officers.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

229

24–8. Information Systems Management Reserve Component officers
a. General career development. ARNG and USAR Information Systems Management officers serve the same role
and mission as their Active Army counterparts. The unique nature of the RC Soldier’s role as a citizen Soldier poses a
significant challenge for professional development. To fulfill the wartime mission of managing information systems
and providing information systems expertise at all levels of command including multinational and Joint Service, the
Information Systems Management officer is dependent upon extensive interaction between the Active Army and the
RC. The quality of the Information Systems Management officers in the ARNG, USAR, and in the individual ready
reserve (IRR) is vital to support this mission. For guidance on RC officer development, see chapter 7.
b. FA qualification and development opportunities.
(1) Information Systems Management officers in the RC have challenging and complex missions. Inherent with
these missions are specific managerial and technical attributes for supervising information management activities,
translating mission needs to computer systems requirements, budgeting for information systems requirements, and
developing/managing information systems. FA 53 officers are tactically and technically proficient and capable of
understanding the scope of an Information Systems Management officer’s duties. A requirement for proficiency in both
peacetime and wartime skills will provide significant educational and experiential challenges. Planned rotation into
progressively challenging FA 53 related positions, while considered essential to producing the best qualified Information Systems Management officer, are limited due to geographical considerations.
(2) Geographic dispersion of Information Systems Management positions constrains RC career progression. To meet
professional development objectives, RC Information Systems Management officers may require rotating between
assignments with USAR TPU, ARNG units, and IMA positions. Often there are insufficient numbers of positions in a
geographic area to continue in Information Systems Management FA assignments. If geographic constraints are such
that the assignment to an Information Systems Management position is not possible, officers should seek assignment in
their basic branch or a related FA required in the geographic region.
(3) TDA organizations host most RC Information Systems Management officer assignments and all Active Guard
Reserve (AGR) FA 53 positions. Their duties and responsibilities are fundamentally the same as their Active Army
counterparts except for those personnel management, administrative, and operational requirements unique to the ARNG
and USAR.
(4) Officers are assigned to the IRR when unable to accept a TPU or ARNG unit assignment. Officers in the IRR
may request assignment to a RTU, IMA position, a tour of ADSW, AT, or ADT. Officers in the IRR may meet PME
requirements by requesting ADT. All RC officers, major and below with less than 15 years of AFS, may request AGR
assignment.
(5) RC FA 53 authorizations will vary as force structure decisions are made and actions to implement them are
taken. USAR officers desiring more information on current authorizations or positions may contact the CFAMO at the
AHRC–St. Louis, Missouri. ARNG officers desiring more information on current authorizations or positions may
contact the ARNG personnel office of the state or territory in which they reside.
(6) RC Officers (captain and above) who acquire information systems management skills, knowledge and attributes
in a civilian workplace or through education and training may apply for constructive credit to award FA 53. Awarding
constructive credit is based on documented experience in information systems management; professional certifications,
advanced degrees, and civilian workplace experience. Candidates should submit requests for constructive credit with
supporting documents through their ARNG or U.S. Army RC chain of command to Commander, USASC&FG, Office
Chief of Signal, ATTN: ATZH–POO, Fort Gordon, Georgia 30905. Supporting documents include (as applicable)—
(a) Cover letter outlining qualifications.
(b) Resume.
(c) DA Form 2–1/officer record brief (ORB) or biographical record brief (BRB).
(d) Transcripts (graduate and/or undergraduate).
(e) OERs/civilian job evaluations.
(f) Civilian training certificates.
(g) Industry certification certificates (MCSE, MCP, CNA, and so on).
(h) Letter(s) of recommendation.
c. Professional development. There are four phases of professional development for RC Information Systems
Management officers. The phases relate to military rank and depict broadly based goals and career opportunities at
each rank so that an officer may expand capabilities and optimize performance. Information Systems Management life
cycle development objectives, RC requirements and an officer’s own strengths, priorities, civilian experience, private
and Service provided educational level, and performance influence his or her professional development. In addition to
the typical duty assignments found in paragraph 24–8b, RC officers are also assigned to other developmental positions,
some of which are listed within the FA qualification standards by grade, as follows:
(1) Captain. Initial entry qualification in Information Systems Management requires officers to complete the ISM
Course at Fort Gordon or obtain a graduate degree as outlined in paragraph 24–8a, above. During this phase, officers
are encouraged to pursue a specialty-related graduate degree. Officers should seek an FA 53 assignment at captain but

230

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

it is not required. Additional typical RC captain positions include systems automation officer, automation management
officer, software engineer officer, and systems operations officer.
(2) Major. The primary professional development objective of Information Systems Management majors in the RC
is to continue to strengthen information systems management skills. During this phase, officers must enroll in and
complete ILE, or its equivalent (50 percent completion required for promotion to lieutenant colonel). Selected RC
officers may attend the ILE common core course at a CL site such as Fort Gordon, GA. FA 53 majors are highly
encouraged to pursue a specialty related graduate degree. Information Systems Management majors should serve a
minimum of 24 months cumulative Service in an Information Systems Management operations or operational support
major position for consideration for FA qualification. Additional typical RC major positions include Information
Management officer and systems analyst.
(3) Lieutenant colonel. Lieutenant colonels can expect assignments to senior staff positions employing them in a
variety of diverse and challenging FA related positions. FA 53 officers should seek PME at the SSC level. Information
Systems Management RC lieutenant colonels are eligible for selection to the rank of colonel upon completion of the
requisite Service requirements listed in chapter 7 of this pamphlet. Lieutenant colonels remain eligible for promotion as
long as they continue to serve in an active status and meet selection criteria. Information Systems Management
lieutenant colonels should serve a minimum of 48 months cumulative Service in FA 53 positions for FA qualification.
Additional typical RC lieutenant colonel positions include assistant DCSIM, automation support officer, and information management plans officer.
(4) Colonel. RC FA 53 colonel positions are limited and reserved for qualified FA 53 officers. The primary
objective for officers during this phase is to use previously developed technical and tactical capabilities, as well as
managerial and executive skills and experience to accomplish the RC information management mission at the Regional
Support Command, State Adjutant General, National Guard Bureau, and DA levels.
