29–6. Requirements, authorizations, and Inventory
a. Goal. To maintain a sustainable, viable career path for FA 59 officers, the field grade inventory adjusts through
constant accessions (captains FD boards/appeals and limited field grade transfers) to fulfill Army requirements while
providing sufficient educational opportunities. The experience gained through such a variety of assignments strengthens
their files prior to consideration for promotion to lieutenant colonel and colonel.
b. OPMS implementation. The number of Strategic Plans and Policy authorizations, by grade, will vary as force
structure decisions are made and implemented. Officers desiring more information on current authorizations or
inventory should contact either the FA 59 proponent manager or the FA 59 career manager. Current authorizations and
requirements are posted to the FA 59 proponent manager Web page http://www.fa-59.army.pentagon.mil/.
29–7. Key officer life cycle initiatives for Strategic Plans and Policy
a. Structure. As with other FA based CFs, FA 59 reflects the field grade structure of the OPMS CF based
management system. All FA 59 authorizations are in the field grades.

268

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

b. Acquire. The principal method of accessing FA 59 officers will be the functional category FD process. FA 59
accessed captains will have successfully completed critical basic branch experiences, attained educational backgrounds
in policy-related fields, and, where applicable, acquired language skills. Although not required for accession into FA
59, company level command is an important developmental assignment that provides indicators of an officer’s aptitude
for successful Service as a strategist. Officers already accessed into other FAs who may be considering a FA transfer
into Strategic Plans and Policy should contact the FA 59 Proponent Manager and the FA 59 career manager at AHRC.
Senior majors and junior lieutenant colonels with strong files and relevant experience (planning and policy) will be
favorably considered. For Strategic Plans and Policy officers, undergraduate or graduate degrees in political science,
international relations, history, government, economics, regional studies, and other social sciences are desirable.
Because of the need for a very broad grounding in the Army, direct commissioning into FA 59 is currently not an
option. FA 59 also encourages officers to gain language skills that support operations in long-standing allied headquarters: German, French, Italian, Spanish, Dutch, Japanese, Korean, and Arabic.
c. Distribute. The Operations Support Division (OSD), OPMD, at AHRC will manage all Strategist FA officer
assignments after designation into FA 59.
d. Deploy. Regardless of current assignment, Strategic Plans and Policy officers must remain personally and
professionally prepared to deploy worldwide.
e. Sustain. Promotions are based upon Army requirements and FA 59 promotions are projected to be at or near
DOPMA rates. FA 59 officers are eligible for below-the-zone promotions and selection if they clearly exhibit superior
long-term performance. FA 59 officers are not currently eligible for field grade level command selection.
f. Develop. All FA 59 officers (YG 1994 to YG 1999) will complete the ILE common core course and the BSAP
after FD. Limited ACS authorizations are available for these year groups and they are encouraged to achieve graduate
degrees on their own initiative. All FA 59 officers (YG 2000 to present) will have the opportunity to attend fullyfunded ACS and attend ILE/AOWC, BSAP and or AMSP. All FA 59 YGs are encouraged to consider fellowships,
professional seminars, and continuing personal development to strengthen their professional backgrounds and prepare
them to serve as multi-skilled officers.
g. Separate. FA 59 officers will separate from the Army in the same manner as all other officers.
29–8. Strategic Plans and Policy Reserve Component officers
a. Career development. RC FA 59 Strategic Plans and Policy officer development objectives and desired experiences will generally parallel Active Army FA 59 officers. The challenge for the Army is to match the unique skills and
expertise of civilian professionals with mission needs and requirements. RC FA 59 officers must be afforded military
education and assignment opportunities so that senior military and civilian leaders can leverage the unique capabilities
that exist among RC FA 59 officers. The goal is to build a talented and fully integrated FA 59 community within the
Total Army, the Joint force, and the U.S. Government.
b. Assignment opportunities. RC Strategic Plans and Policy officers can expect assignment opportunities similar to
those of Active Army officers (RC Strategic Plans and Policy officers include National Guard officers). In addition,
there are positions exclusive to the Reserves and National Guard that exist in response to the changing geo-strategic
environment. Whether through mobilization of TPUs, mobilization tours for IMAs, extended Active Duty assignments,
or the limited call to Active Duty program (see below), RC FA 59 officers will serve at all levels within the Army,
Joint community, and the Department of Defense. The success of an RC strategist is not measured by length of Service
in any one component or control group, but by the officer’s experience, abilities, and performance. FA 59 assignments
are made based upon the USAR, AGR, and IMA officers available and qualified coupled with military necessity and
requirements. Civilian acquired skills, advanced military and civilian education, and demonstrated abilities to function
in a strategic environment exist among a diverse pool of RC strategists.
c. Limited call to Active Duty (LCAD). Interested RC strategists are encouraged to pursue the LCAD program. This
enables RC strategists to re-enter the Active Army while maintaining continuity of Service. Once accessed into the
Active Army, LCAD officers are assigned, promoted, and educated in the active Army. Those officers who are
interested should contact the Active Duty FA 59 career manager.
d. FA 59 development opportunities.
(1) A diverse and fluid career. The competing demands of civilian and military life pose a challenge for the
professional development of the FA 59 RC strategist. RC strategists should follow Active Army officer development
patterns as closely as possible. However, a FA 59 RC officer’s development and assignment progression can be
characterized by its ability to adapt to changes. Civilian professional development can benefit the Total Army, and
should be leveraged. To meet military career development objectives, RC officers must be willing to rotate between
ARNG and USAR TPU, IRR, IMA program, and the AGR programs. These transfers are necessitated by individual
career paths, military requirements, geographical considerations, and the need to provide as many officers as possible
the opportunity to serve with troops in leadership and staff positions. The RC strategist should expect numerous and
rewarding transitions from civilian to military life. It is important to be flexible and weigh various options as
assignments and schools come available. FA 59s should seek TDY assignments and/or mobilization as an IMA.
Mobilized TPUs will present opportunities. Transferring to the IRR may be necessary while completing mandatory

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

269

military educational requirements necessary to build a career and advance as a FA 59 RC officer. RC strategists should
contact the FA 59 RC career manager to review options and opportunities.
(2) Education and training. Due to the complexity and diversity of assignments in the FA 59 field, RC officers must
continually develop their knowledge and analytical skills. RC strategists will be offered opportunities to pursue
continuing education and training (civilian and military) and government internship programs to improve skills.
Strategists in the grade of major should attend resident BSAP and complete the DSC. RC officers will have increased
time windows to complete requirements.
e. Life cycle development model. The RC life cycle development model for FA 59 RC Strategic Plans and Policy
officers mirrors that for Active Army officers, except that assignments are not limited to one component or control
group. Figure 29–2, below, illustrates a typical RC FA 59 career.

Chapter 30
Nuclear and Counterproliferation Functional Area
30–1. Unique features of the Nuclear and Counterproliferation functional area
a. Purpose of the Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA. The Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA within the plans
development group of the operations support functional category provides trained, educated and experienced officers
who apply knowledge and expertise in nuclear related combating weapons of mass destruction (WMD) mission areas to
support the development of national and military strategy, plans and policy; conducting nuclear weapons effects
research and analysis; analysis of nuclear weapons consequences of execution; nuclear consequence management;
international treaty formulation and verification; characterization and elimination of nuclear-related facilities and
infrastructure; and planning the employment of nuclear weapons to support theater and strategic operations.
b. Unique functions performed by the Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA. The mission of FA 52 is to provide
technical advice and support in developing national and military strategy, plans, and policy recommendations to Army,
combatant command, DOD, and interagency leadership in nuclear related combating WMD mission areas. To accomplish this mission, the Nuclear and Counterproliferation officer performs the following FA 52 functions:
(1) Conducts research and analysis of nuclear and related weapons effects.
(2) Assists in forming national and military nuclear weapons strategy, plans, and policies.
(3) Assists in identifying requirements for the development, operation, and sustainment of nuclear weapons systems.
(4) Serves as a staff officer in support of warfighting forces in nuclear weapons employment and nuclear related
combating weapons of mass destruction.
(5) Provides technical expertise to assure the operational effectiveness, survivability, and endurance of our forces
based upon nuclear and other threats.
(6) Provides technical assistance in target analysis and employment planning of nuclear and advanced conventional
weapons.
(7) Assists in international arms control treaty formulation and verification.
(8) Assists in coordinating the interagency (that is, Department of Energy, Department of Homeland Security, and
Intelligence Community) and DOD nuclear-related research and operational activities.
(9) Assists in the formulation of multinational nuclear standardization agreements.
(10) Educates USMA cadets and other Government personnel in nuclear weapons, nuclear weapons effects, and the
nuclear sciences.
(11) Conducts analysis of personnel, equipment, and mission vulnerability to nuclear effects.
(12) Conducts technical analysis to support nuclear weapon stockpile surety.
(13) Supports the preparation, coordination, and maintenance of nuclear accident incident response and assistance
(NAIRA) policies, procedures, and plans.
(14) Provides technical oversight and management in support of national nonproliferation and counterproliferation
programs (for example, cooperative threat reduction (CTR) and proliferation security initiative (PSI)).
(15) Operates, oversees, and regulates research or testing nuclear reactors and weapons effects simulators.
(16) Provides technical oversight and management of nuclear modeling and simulation efforts.
(17) Participates in the characterization and elimination of nuclear-related facilities and infrastructure.
c. Unique features of work in the FA. Work within the Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA requires the application
of technical skills in their military applications. Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers are frequently the sole subject
matter experts within their command or organization. They will—
(1) Serve as staff or liaison officers in Army, Joint, Defense, and interagency organizations.
(2) Serve as instructors in the Department of Physics and Department of Chemistry and Life Sciences at the USMA,
the Department of Engineering Physics at the Air Force Institute of Technology, the NATO School, and the Defense
Nuclear Weapons School.
(3) Serve as Military Research Associates at Department of Energy National Laboratories.
(4) Serve in fellowship positions within interagency organizations and through the TWI program.
30–2. Officer characteristics required
The Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA requires officers who are skilled in leadership at all levels; who are proficient
in branch tactics, techniques, and procedures; who possess strong Army Values, leader attributes, and skills; and who
fully understand the key leadership actions that must be taken to assure success. There are skills, knowledge, and
attributes unique to this FA that require professional development and FA 52 candidates must acquire or possess them
to ensure success.
a. Values, attributes, skills, and actions common to all.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

271

(1) Army Values. Consistent with the new OER.
(2) Leader attributes. Fundamental qualities and characteristics.
(3) Leader skills. Skill development is part of self-development; prerequisite to action.
(4) Leadership actions. Major activities leaders perform: influencing, operating, and improving.
b. Required skills. FA 52 officers must fully comprehend the organization, structure and doctrine of the warfighting
Army as it evolves into the 21st Century. In addition, they must—
(1) Possess an undergraduate degree in any mathematics, science or engineering discipline and/or operational
experience with weapons of mass destruction at the company grade level.
(2) Possess the ability to obtain a master’s degree in a nuclear related field.
(3) Routinely serve in staff positions where guidance is minimal and close interaction with senior-level decisionmakers is common.
(4) Apply highly technical scientific concepts to more military-specific issues and applications.
(5) Be capable of communicating this technical expertise in either written or oral communications.
(6) Be extremely adept at organizing workload, assigning tasks, and mentoring civilian and military subordinates.
c. Specialized knowledge. Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers must maintain current knowledge on Army
organization, structure, and doctrine. They also must—
(1) Possess the technical expertise and operational understanding of nuclear and related weapons effects relative to
their FA.
(2) Remain current on developments in research and applications in both the civilian and military environments for
possible application to their area of expertise.
(3) Remain current on the national and military strategies for combating weapons of mass destruction.
d. Unique attributes. Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers must possess the highest standards of discretion,
integrity and professional ethic. In addition, they will—
(1) Be both technologically and operationally-oriented.
(2) Think in the abstract and be able to apply the engineering approach to problem-solving.
(3) Be able to obtain a Top Secret clearance with access to Sensitive Compartmented Information (SCI).
30–3. Critical Nuclear and Counterproliferation Functional Area Officer development and assignments
a. General. Officers are functionally designated into the Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA by a FDB during their
7th YOS based upon the needs of the Army, officer preference, military experience, and, in some cases, civil schooling.
However, they are not generally considered for a Nuclear and Counterproliferation assignment until they have served in
a captain-level basic branch developmental assignment. Most officers will not receive a Nuclear and Counterproliferation assignment until undergoing the FDB and attendance of ILE and advanced civil schooling, as required.
b. FA Qqualification and development. Officers who are functionally designated into FA 52 should complete the FA
52 qualification course, the Nuclear and Counterproliferation Officer (FA 52) Course (NCP52), taught at the Defense
Nuclear Weapons School of the Defense Threat Reduction University, to gain the basic skills necessary for success in
the FA. NCP52 provides FA 52 officers with an introduction to the planning skills related to combating WMD, an
overview of the U.S. nuclear weapons program, an introduction to current WMD issues, and an orientation on the
nuclear weapons and combating WMD communities. As officers progress through their careers, they will be afforded
other FA-related and Army-unique educational opportunities based upon their performance of duties and the needs of
the Army.
(1) Captain. There are only limited FA 52 requirements for captains, therefore, a FA 52 assignment as a captain is
not a requirement for promotion to major, but could enhance selection into FA 52 at FD. The years following
successful completion of a branch developmental assignment are an opportunity for an officer to attend advanced civil
school or begin a FA assignment prior to functional designation. FD normally occurs in an officer’s 7th YOS. Officers
who are functionally designated into FA 52 can expect to serve primarily in Nuclear and Counterproliferation
assignments for the remainder of their careers.
(2) Major. After selection for major, Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers will then serve primarily in their FA,
with an occasional opportunity for assignment to a branch immaterial position. These billets ensure that FA 52 officers
continue to sustain the knowledge and understanding of the operational force. All Nuclear and Counterproliferation
officers must complete the requirements of ILE. ILE, for FA 52 officers consists of the completion of the command
and general staff officer’s course common core curriculum (ILE Phase 1) and the FA 52 Qualification Course (NCP52)
(ILE Phase 2). There is no required sequence for the completion of the two phases of ILE. Some will complete
graduate school to prepare for Nuclear and Counterproliferation officer assignments requiring additional skills. FA 52
majors serve primarily in entry-level positions in Defense agencies and ACOMs, where they work in staff positions
across all of the mission areas of combating WMD. Typical FA 52 developmental positions at the grade of Major
include—
(a) Combating WMD planner, Defense Threat Reduction Agency.
(b) Nuclear research officer, Defense Threat Reduction Agency.

272

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

(c) Proliferation policy analyst, Defense Threat Reduction Agency.
(d) Operations officer, at Joint staff J3.
(e) Combating WMD Planner, at U.S. Strategic Command.
(f) Nuclear policy analyst, at Combatant Command Headquarters.
(g) Nuclear research officer, Defense Intelligence Agency.
(h) Plans and operations officer, Joint Task Force Civil Support.
(i) Plans and operations officer, 20th Support Command (CBRNE).
(3) Lieutenant colonel. Lieutenant colonels are generally assigned to senior staff positions, where they can fully use
their knowledge of the Army and their FA. A limited number of opportunities exist for FA 52 officers to attend
graduate school, at both the master’s and Ph.D. levels, to prepare them for FA 52 assignments requiring additional
skills. Officers who serve successfully in a FA 52 lieutenant colonel developmental positions and have the required
time in grade are qualified to compete for promotion to colonel. Typical FA 52 developmental positions at the grade of
lieutenant colonel include:
(a) Branch Chief, Defense Threat Reduction Agency.
(b) Defense Threat Reduction Agency LNO to combatant command.
(c) Combating WMD planner, Defense Threat Reduction Agency.
(d) Branch Chief, Defense Intelligence Agency.
(e) Combating WMD plans and policy officer, DCS, G–3/5/7.
(f) WMD operations officer, Joint staff, J3.
(g) Nuclear weapons staff officer, Army Nuclear & Chemical Agency.
(h) WMD plans and policy officer, combatant command J3 or J5.
(i) Nuclear planner, U.S. Strategic Command.
(4) Colonel. As senior practitioners in their FA, they will primarily serve as Nuclear and Counterproliferation
officers on Army, Joint, or Defense staffs or may be assigned to branch immaterial positions.
c. Branch immaterial and FA generalist assignments. Captains and above can expect to serve in branch immaterial
assignments and be afforded the opportunity to broaden their experience by serving in positions outside of FA 52 and
their functional category. As a minimum, officers can expect to complete one assignment outside of FA 52 prior to
selection for colonel.
d. Joint assignments. During their careers, most FA 52 will be afforded the opportunity for an assignment that
provides them a JIIM experience. A majority of Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA positions are on the Joint Duty
Assignment List (JDAL). Officers assigned to those billets may attend JPME and may be designated as a JSO (SI 3L)
upon successful tour completion. Additionally, a number of FA 52 positions are found in Joint and Defense agencies,
even though those positions may not be listed on the JDAL. Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers are not generally
considered for Joint duty assignments until selected for major. Even though Joint experience is important to the Army
and individual officers for advancement into senior leadership positions, not all FA 52 officers will receive Joint
assignments. This will not preclude their selection to the rank of colonel.
30–4. Assignment preferences and precedence
The assignment sequencing in a FA is not as rigid as that of a branch. However, the professional development of
Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA officers has certain requirements to ensure all of the Army’s FA 52 officers are
well grounded in operations. Officers will receive their initial FA training through attendance of the Nuclear and
Counterproliferation Officer (FA 52) Course at the Defense Nuclear Weapons School, Kirtland, AFB, NM. FA 52
officers, less those assigned as instructors at USMA, can anticipate that their first assignment will be with the Defense
Threat Reduction Agency (DTRA). As the organization with the largest number of assigned FA 52 officers, an entrylevel assignment at DTRA will serve as a foundation for future assignments within the nuclear weapons and combating
WMD communities. As part of their continued development, they may also serve at least one assignment in a position
outside of FA 52.
a. Preferences. The Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA has multiple opportunities that allow for numerous career
development paths. The goal of the professional development of FA 52 officers is to produce officers with a broad base
of skills in multiple areas of nuclear research, nuclear operations, and combating WMD and to apply those skills across
the full spectrum of WMD operations. Assignments in the Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA will be made to
develop the officer’s ability to achieve that goal. Requests from officers for assignments that do not contribute to
achieving this goal will likely be rejected.
b. Precedence. Assignment to developmental FA positions will have a precedence, although there is flexibility on
the sequence of assignments. Most Nuclear and Counter-proliferation FA billets will be designated as requiring
advanced education, either military or civilian. Officers assigned to those jobs must complete the required courses prior
to reporting to their duty assignments.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

273

30–5. Duration of critical officer life cycle assignments
Most assignments of Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers will be 24–36 months in length. Officers serving their
initial, entry-level assignment at DTRA can anticipate that it will be 48 months in length, with the goal for the officer
to serve 24 months in two different directorates in DTRA. Tours could be longer in areas of high concentration of
billets such as the National Capital Region. OCONUS locations will continue to require specific tour lengths.
a. Key Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA Qualification Positions. There are no specific Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA assignments required for FA qualification. Completion of the applicable-level courses as outlined in
paragraph 30–3, and successful completion of a Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA tour are the only requirements for
continued FA development at the field grade level. Officers are encouraged to broaden their individual and professional
skills by seeking alternating assignments in positions that vary both in type and echelon of organization. This variation
will provide a balance between the technical and operational aspects of FA 52 and provide the officer with a
perspective than spans from the operational to strategic levels. Though preferred, there is no requirement for a Nuclear
and Counterproliferation officer to have completed a previous FA assignment prior to assignment to a Joint command
or agency.

FA life cycle and the range of developmental assignments within the FA.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

30–6. Requirements, authorizations, and inventory
a. Goal. The goal is to maintain a healthy, viable career path for Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers. To do
this, the field grade inventory must be optimized in order to fulfill FA, branch immaterial, and multi-functional
authorization requirements and to provide field grade officers sufficient time for FA development prior to promotion to
lieutenant colonel and colonel. Sufficient inventory must be available to meet authorization requirements, while
allowing sufficient FA 52 officers to attend professional military education, functional training, and advanced civilian
education required for the positions in which they will later serve.
b. Implementation. The number of FA 52 authorizations, by grade, will vary as force structure decisions are made
and actions to implement them are taken. Officers desiring more information on current authorizations or inventory, by
grade, should contact either the FA 52 personnel proponent or the FA 52 assignments officer at AHRC.
30–7. Key officer life cycle initiatives/alternatives for the Nuclear and Counterproliferation functional
area
a. Structure. FA 52 positions exist in Army agencies, headquarters staffs, Joint commands, and defense and national
agencies. The majority of Nuclear and Counterproliferation-related billets will be in Joint and defense agencies.
b. Acquire. Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers comprising a particular year group are functionally designated
into FA 52 in their 7th YOS. The criteria for selecting an officer to the Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA include:
type of civilian degree, grade point average, personal preference, WMD operational experience, and manner of
performance.
c. Distribute. After functional designation into FA 52 at the 7th YOS, all Nuclear and Counterproliferation officer
assignments will be managed by the OSD, OPMD, at AHRC.
d. Develop. FA 52 incorporates a professional officer development career plan offering maximum diversity for
schooling and assignment. As Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers progress through their careers, in addition to
advanced military schooling opportunities, they become eligible for ACS in nuclear-related fields. These are available
at a wide variety of academic institutions, and prepare them for positions of increased responsibility and augment their
technical expertise.
e. Sustain. Officers in the Operations support functional category will compete within that functional category for
promotions to major, lieutenant colonel, and colonel.
f. Compensate. Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers will be financially compensated in the same manner as all
other officers. A majority of Nuclear and Counterproliferation FA billets requires officers with specialized degrees.
Therefore, fully-funded ACE opportunities exist for FA 52 officers at both the Master’s and Ph.D. levels.
g. Separate. FA 52 officers will separate from the Army in the same manner as all other officers.
30–8. Nuclear and Counterproliferation (FA 52) Reserve Component officers
a. General career development. RC describes both the USAR and ARNG and, unless otherwise indicated, references
to the RC are applicable to both. RC Officers serve the same roles as their Active Army counterparts. The unique
circumstances within the RC pose a challenge for professional development. RC officers are expected to follow Active
Army officer development patterns as closely as possible, except that RC officers have, in some cases, increased
windows to complete mandatory education requirements. To meet professional development objectives, RC FA 52
officers must be willing to rotate among ARNG and the USAR TPU, IMA program, and the AGR program. For more
guidance on RC officer development, see chapter 7.
b. RC officer qualification and development. RC Nuclear and Counterproliferation (FA 52) officers can expect
assignments that are similar to their Active Army counterparts. The exception is that these assignments will also
include those separate RC FA 52, administrative, and operational reporting requirements unique to the ARNG and
USAR. The success of an RC officer is not measured by the length of Service in any one component or control group,
but by the officer’s breadth of experience, duty performance, and adherence to the requirements described herein.
Every attempt will be made to assign RC Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers to FA 52 or branch immaterial
positions. Unlike their Active Army counterparts, geographic constraints limit the ability of RC officers to stay in FA
52 positions throughout their career. When barriers such as this deny the opportunity to successfully participate in the
USAR, officers are encouraged to seek qualification and utilization in another FA. RC qualification standards will
mirror those of the Active Army whenever possible. They are as follows:
(1) Lieutenant. N/A.
(2) Captain. There are limited requirements for RC FA 52 captains and these are considered entry level. Nuclear
and Counterproliferation FA experience as a captain is not a requirement for promotion to major, but would enhance
selection to the operations support functional group. RC officer do not currently undergo FD and are designated into
FA 52 after successful completion of the FA 52 qualification course.
(3) Major. Currently, RC Majors are not functional designated, but may serve in any specialty for which they have

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

275

the requisite background and/or experience. FA 52 major positions can be found in TPU, IMA, and AGR programs. All
RC FA 52 officers should complete 50 percent of CGSC. RC FA 52 officers should attend the Nuclear and
Counterproliferation Officer (FA 52) Course (NCP52) during their first year of assignment to a FA 52 entry level
position.
(4) Lieutenant colonel. RC FA 52 lieutenant colonels should complete CGSC within 3 years of promotion to
lieutenant colonel. FA 52 positions can be found in TPU and IMA programs, with positions in the AGR program
anticipated.
(5) Colonel. All Nuclear and Counterproliferation officers selected for colonel should apply for SSC (non-resident)
Corresponding Studies Course if not selected for the resident course. Currently, because there are only RC FA 52
colonel positions in the IMA program, officers selected for colonel can expect to serve primarily in branch immaterial
positions.
(6) Life cycle development model. The RC life cycle development model for FA 52 officers is shown at figure 30–2,
below, for USAR AGR officers, ANG M–Day officers, and USAR TPU/IMA officers.
(7) Civilian acquired skills. Many RC officers are qualified to serve in FA 52 based upon their civilian education
and civilian job experience. RC individuals with educational backgrounds in physics or nuclear engineering or work
experience in the nuclear weapons, nuclear power, emergency response, or related areas are strongly encouraged to
apply for FA 52.

Chapter 31
Force Management Functional Area
31–1. Unique features of the Force Management functional area
a. Purpose of the the Force Management FA. Force Management is a critical operating function for the Army. The
Force Management FA provides distinctively skilled officers who are primarily integrators for requirements determination, combat development, organizational development and documentation, program development and funding, and
materiel solutions development and fielding at operational and strategic levels of the Army and Joint forces. Force
Management officers are trained, educated, and qualified in critical aspects of the force management process to ensure
that forces are shaped and provided with the capabilities necessary to support the missions of geographic combatant
commands.
b. Unique functions. Force Management officers (FA 50s) are experienced in managing the organizational and
materiel changes that are fundamental to an evolving modular Army. These officers are critical to accomplishing the
Army’s Title 10 responsibilities of organizing, manning, training, equipping, and supporting land combat forces. FA
50s are highly educated, trusted advisors at all levels who serve as the SMEs on the technical processes of force
management. Force Management officers are experts at force development; the process which involves determining
warfighting requirements, designing operational and institutional force structure, identifying, and allocating authorized
resources, and analyzing second and third order effects of changes to requirements, structure, and resources. FA 50s at
division, corps, ACOMs, and ASCCs provide the warfighting command the flexibility to adapt to unforeseen organizational and materiel challenges. The Force Management officer is also an expert at force integration; the process that
manages the integration and synchronization of Army requirements across most of the Doctrine, organizations, training,
materiel, leader development and education, personnel, and facilities (DOTMLPF) domains. FA 50 proponency falls
within the operations support functional category within OPMS.
c. Work in the Force Management FA. Force management is demanding, challenging, and rewarding, providing
officers the opportunity to directly affect development of the Army of the future. A Force Management officer is
involved in—
(1) Designing organizations to support Army and Joint warfighting concepts and doctrine.
(2) Supporting the development of tables of organization and equipment (TOE), Basis-of-Issue Plans (BOIP), and
Manpower Requirements Criteria (MARC).
(3) Determining the structure and composition of Army operating and generating forces through the Total Army
Analysis (TAA) Process.
(4) Determining manpower and equipment allocations for the planned, programmed and budgeted forces and related
organizations and equipment within the Planning, Programming, Budgeting, and Execution (PPBE) System.
(5) Developing, allocating, synchronizing documentation and executing organizational authorizations (Modified
TOEs, (MTOEs)) and tables of distribution and allowances (TDAs)); conducting affordability, supportability, and
executability assessments; and monitoring and adjusting execution of programs through concept plan and command
plan processes.
(6) Coordinating activation/inactivation/reorganization of units, processing and analysis of operational needs statements (ONS), and fielding of new equipment and systems.
(7) Analyzing cost effectiveness of personnel and materiel solutions.
(8) Analyzing and developing requirements for training programs, training devices, and simulations in support of
new systems.
(9) Determining cost effectiveness and risk mitigation factors associated with establishing the Army’s program
objective memorandum (POM).
31–2. Officer characteristics required
The Force Management FA requires officers who are skilled in leadership at all levels; who understand military
operations; who possess strong Army Values, leader attributes and skills; and who fully understand the key leadership
actions that must be taken to adapt the Army as change occurs. Force Management officers also have the technical
aptitude necessary to grasp complex, abstract ideas.
a. Required skills. Force Management officers at all levels must be able to—
(1) Operate routinely in high level staff assignments where guidance may be minimal and close interaction with
senior level decisionmakers is frequent.
(2) Express their ideas clearly, concisely, and accurately in both oral and written communication.
(3) Thoroughly develop issues and clearly articulate recommendations and their potential second and third order
effects to senior level decisionmakers.
(4) Reduce raw data for effective use by senior level decisionmakers.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

277

(5) Organize, integrate, and lead work groups of military and civilian specialists to solve specific force management
problems.
(6) Conduct innovative research on evolving force management processes or developmental Army systems or
capabilities.
b. Specialized knowledge. Force Management officers require specialized detailed knowledge of Army organization,
structure, and doctrine to be SMEs in managing organizational and materiel change. Force Management officers must:
(1) Possess a thorough understanding of Army force management processes, gained through specialized education
and training courses and through repeated duty assignments at operational and strategic levels of command.
(2) Understand the organization of the Army, ARNG and USAR, their Title 10 USC (Armed Forces) and Title 32
USC (Army National Guard) responsibilities, and the missions, roles, and functions of their major commands.
(3) Understand, in broad terms, the organization of the DOD; the principal strategic planning documents (National
Military Strategy (NMS), National Defense Strategy (NDS), National Security Strategy (NSS), Defense Planning
Guidance (DPG), and the formal and informal procedures and processes for resourcing the DOD and the Services.
(4) Understand Joint warfighting concepts and the integration of Joint and Service systems (planning and resourcing) at the strategic, operational, and tactical levels.
(5) Understand both formal and informal systems of the U.S. Government, interagency processes, Joint Strategic
Planning System (JSPS), and PPBE.
(6) Understand how national issues, including political, military, economic, social, inter-Governmental, and international/multinational challenges affect Army and Joint force management.
31–3. Critical officer development and assignments
a. General. Force Management officers possess significant skills in organizing, equipping, and resourcing the Army
and are the creative managers of change for the Army and within DOD. Officers at the grade of O3 or higher who are
interested in the Force Management FA or who will be required to serve in positions coded for SI 3R should complete
initial force management training prior to performing duties in any position coded for SI 3R. This training is open to
any officer and can be completed regardless of the officer’s rank. Attending the 4-week Advanced Force Management
Course (AFMC) at the Army Force Management School (AFMS) at Fort Belvoir, VA, results in award of the SI 3R
(Force Management) indicating familiarity with force management processes. Officers selected for Functional Designation into FA 50 will attend this AFMC training together with the follow-on FA 50 Qualification Course (QC) to
designate them as FA 50 officers. Ideally, the Force Management officer will begin his/her FA career at HQDA level
to ensure a solid grounding in DA force management processes and to enhance future utility when assigned to units at
operational Army level. Following initial assignment, the Force Management officer must seek to broaden and hone
his/her skills, knowledge, and experiences at every grade. Force Management officers will increase their expertise and
broaden their skill sets by seeking subsequent assignments that alternate between organizational and materiel orientation and cross echelons between ARSTAF, ACOM, operational units (ASCC, corps, division), and Joint levels as they
progress through their careers.
b. FA qualification and development. All officers functionally designated into FA 50 attend the 4-week AFMC.
Officers in YG 92 and earlier are considered qualified if they have completed the 4-week AFMC. Officers in later year
YGs must complete the follow-on FA 50 QC (implemented in 2005) to complete their qualification in the FA. The FA
50 QC provides an understanding of the logical flow of operational concepts, requirements determination, capabilitiesbased assessments, organizational design and documentation, equipment and manpower resourcing, and materiel
acquisition and fielding. The QC blends the principles of Army force management with liberal practical exercises on
the component systems of force management as it builds on the AFMC foundation throughout the 10 week curriculum.
Taken together, the ILE core course, the AFMC, and the FA 50 QC will provide the officer the required training and
education for intermediate career education requirements and JPME 1 qualification. Following this qualification,
officers may complete a brief but focused assignment oriented curriculum to prepare them with the skills specific to
their first assignment in force management. Additionally, opportunities outside the typical FA professional development
path do exist for some officers. Pursuing an advanced degree (see table 31–3, below) is highly recommended and very
desirable anytime in a Force Management officer’s career. Officers may apply for the SAMS at Fort Leavenworth, KS.
Interested officers should submit requests for attendance and exception to policy to their branch manager and the FA
50 proponency office. Force Managers at the lieutenant colonel rank that are competitive for selection for SSC should
consider ranking the Industrial College of the Armed Forces (ICAF) the top consideration for slating. Force managers
should actively pursue TDY opportunities in order to increase their operational exposure in major theaters and JIIM
experience as well. JIIM is an evolving set of opportunities. Officers should ensure that experiences outside traditional
branch or FA positions, even for short periods, should be documented by supervisors in performance evaluations.
Future revisions to this manual will contain more specific guidance on tracking and crediting JIIM type exposure or
experience.
(1) Captain.
(a) Qualification. There are currently no FA requirements for captains; however, captains have the opportunity to

278

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

attend the initial SI 3R producing force management training (AFMC) and serve in 3R-coded positions once they have
completed any basic branch requirements and required schooling.
(b) Development. Officers indicate their preferences for FD at their 7th YOS or prior to the Major Selection Board.
Generally, officers who are designated FA 50 will be eligible for a force management assignment after they have met
all the basic branch requirements as a captain and completed the ILE and JPME 1 qualification training. Captains
desiring to serve in a force management assignment should work directly with the AHRC FA 50 assignment officer
concerning options for their last company grade assignment prior to consideration for promotion to major. This will
allow sufficient time to coordinate the scheduling of initial force management training and a follow-on force management assignment to an authorized billet. Although no requirements for FA qualification exist at the rank of captain,
training and experience in operational assignments provide the officer with a solid foundation for force management
work. Additionally, a 3R-coded assignment as a captain may enhance the officer’s chances of functional designation
into the Force Management FA. FD occurs normally at the 7th YOS, but not later than selection for promotion to
major. Officers who are designated to come to FA 50 in the FD process may serve in Force Management assignments
for the remainder of their careers.

(2) Major.
(a) Qualification. In order to be well qualified at the rank of major an officer must complete the following
requirements:
1. Complete ILE curriculum.
2. Complete the FA 50 QC.
3. Serve successfully in a FA 50 major authorized KD or developmental position. The above criteria combined with
time in grade make the officer eligible for consideration for promotion to lieutenant colonel. FA 50 majors serve
primarily as a force management specialist or as individual action officers with specific focus in force management
areas of responsibility. Officers should seek force management assignments that provide additional breadth to their
experiences and skill sets, and should strive to serve in positions that exercise force development or force integration
processes at several levels. Majors, as a minimum, should successfully serve in one or more of the following 6 KD
positions:
a. Requirements synchronization officer, at the Army G3.
b. Force management officer, at ACOM / ASCC or the Army G3.
c. Force modernization officer, at Division, Corps, or ACOM/ASCC.
d. System synchronization officer, at the Army G8.
e. Joint force manager, at Joint staff J8 or at the Army G8.
f. Force Management Program analyst, at the Army G8.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

279

4. Serve successfully in one of these 4 developmental positions:
a. Force structure officer, at ACOM / ASCC, or Army G3.
b. Force structure analyst at ACOM or Army G8.
c. Force design officer at ACOM.
d. Combat developer at ACOM.
(b) Utilization. Force Management majors can expect utilization at either HQDA or at the operational level
(division, corps, and ASCC). Some majors could be utilized as force managers at ACOM level headquarters. Majors
should work toward the completion of a master’s degree in a primary or associated discipline (see tables 31–2 and
31–3, below) either through fully-funded programs or on their own initiative.
(3) Lieutenant colonel.
(a) Qualification. In order to be well qualified at the rank of lieutenant colonel, an officer should complete the
following requirements:
1. Complete the FA qualifications for major.
2. Serve successfully in a FA 50 lieutenant colonel authorized key developmental or developmental position. The
above criteria combined with time in grade qualify the officer for consideration for promotion to colonel. FA 50
lieutenant colonels are generally assigned to supervisory positions or to positions on senior level staffs. Lieutenant
colonels are expected to understand the programmatic underpinnings of requirement determination, materiel solutions,
force design, and resource programming and funding. They guide and review the force management work of subordinates and apply analytical assessment techniques to a wide range of military force management and managerial issues.
Force Management lieutenant colonels should successfully serve in one or more of the following 6 KD positions:
a. Deputy division chief at the Army G3.
b. Branch or team chief at ACOM, the Army G3 or G8.
c. Force integration officer at corps, ACOM or the Army G3.
d. Force developer at corps or ACOM.
e. Requirement synchronization officer/system synchronization officer at the Army G3 and G8.
f. Joint force manager at Joint staff or the Army G8.
3. Serve successfully in one of these 3 developmental positions:
a. Force manager at ACOM or the Army G3.
b. Force analysis manager at ACOM, Army G3 or G8.
c. Command manager at the Army G3.
(b) Utilization. Force Management lieutenant colonels can expect utilization at either HQDA, ACOM, or at the
operational level (division, corps, ASCC) and should aggressively seek different types of jobs within Force Management authorizations and structure to broaden their force management experience. Additionally, it is in the best interest
of the officer to work in FA 50 authorized positions that increase their experiences in leadership. It is highly
recommended that lieutenant colonels complete a master’s degree program in a primary or associated discipline (refer
to tables 31–2 and 31–3, below). Assignments outside of the FA do exist and the opportunities to compete for
nominative assignments are available to the Force Management officer.

(4) Colonel. As senior force managers, colonels serve in assignments that require both technical force management
and managerial skills. They should be able to oversee and direct diverse force management efforts and analytical
studies in order to determine the best feasible force management solution. All FA 50 coded colonel billets are critical
assignments and will require a trained force management officer to fill the authorization. Colonels should have a broad
background in analytical processes, and possess the following qualifications:
(a) Joint qualified (3A or 3L).
(b) SSC graduate.
(c) Serve successfully in a FA 50 colonel FA authorized position. These required educational and duty assignment
milestones qualify the officer for consideration for promotion to brigadier general.
c. FA generalist assignments. Assignments outside of the functional category do exist and the opportunities to
compete for nominative assignments are available to the Force Management officer. However, the intent of the Army is
to utilize its senior level force managers in positions that make the best use of their force management experience.
d. Joint assignments. FA 50 FA positions exist on the JDAL for major and above. Joint experience, while highly
encouraged, is not required for an FA 50 officer to be promoted to colonel. Officers seeking assignment opportunities
within the JCS or OSD should first successfully complete at least one Army Force Management assignment, preferably
at the DA or ACOM staff level.
e. ACS. FA 50 majors and lieutenant colonels can compete for a fully-funded Masters in Business Administration or
System Engineering with a concentration in Force Management once they are FA qualified. FA 50 sends selected
officers to attend a 16 month curriculum at George Mason University in Fairfax, Virginia or the Naval Postgraduate
School at Monterey, California. The curriculum year begins in August and ends in December of the following year.
Officers assessed into the ACS program will incur a three-year commitment upon completion of the degree studies. To
compete for the ACS program, the officer must meet the minimum standards outlined in AR 621–1. Interested officers
are asked to contact the FA 50 branch manager at AHRC no later than 31 May of the current year to ensure timely
preparation of their ACS packets.
f. Fellowships. FA 50 majors and lieutenant colonels can compete for a RAND Arroyo Center Fellowship. RAND is
a Federally Funded Research and Development Center (FFRDC) with its headquarters in Santa Monica, California. FA
50 sends one officer a year to serve a 12-month tour with RAND Arroyo Center in Alexandria, Virginia. The
fellowship offers the officer the opportunity to conduct in-depth research and analysis on critical force management
issues at the DA and DOD levels, as well as to become a published author as a part of this fellowship. Interested
officers undergo a rigorous interview and selection process to ensure that the best qualified officer represents the force
management community. Upon successful completion of the one-year tour, the officer incurs a three-year commitment.
Officers interested in competing for this Fellowship must meet the requirements outlined in AR 621–7. Interested
officers and should contact the FA 50 branch manager at AHRC no later than 31 May of the current year to ensure
timely preparation of their fellowship packets. It will be advantageous for officers to complete a master’s degree in a
primary or associate discipline (see tables 31–2 and 31–3, above) prior to competing for the RAND Fellowship. Further
information on fellowships may be obtained by contacting the FA 50 personnel proponency office.
31–4. Assignment preferences and precedence
The professional development of a Force Management officer requires that the officer be exposed to a variety of force
management related work. The fundamentals of force management procedures and processes do not change rapidly
over time, but their application varies to meet the needs of contemporary operating environments. After receiving their
initial training, FA 50 officers should seek various types of force management assignments in different types of
organizations to foster their professional development and to broaden and hone the critical skills necessary for success
at senior levels.
a. Preferences. Force Management officers manage and lead change; they become an invaluable tool for the
commander from requirements determination to organizational and materiel solutions. The goal of the FA is to produce
officers skilled in the technical processes of force management, but retaining their broad understanding of the
operational Army. The Force Management officer is capable of managing the processes of requirements determination,
DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

281

organizational development and documentation, fielding and integration of new equipment and systems, and integrating
these processes to facilitate Army evolution. Officers should also develop skill at quantitative and qualitative analysis
throughout their careers. Assignments in the FA provide the officer exposure to a number of organizations that require
force management skills and attributes so that the officer develops a fuller understanding of the application of force
management techniques throughout the military.
b. Precedence. The sequencing of assignments within the FA is flexible; although, in some instances, precedence for
assignments exists. Officers who have not yet met KD or developmental requirements at their respective rank may be
given the precedence for assignment to FA 50 authorized positions. An officer’s first field grade assignment is in a FA
50 authorized coded developmental position, and officers can expect subsequent FA 50 assignments throughout the
Army and Joint staffs.
31–5. Duration of critical officer life cycle assignments
Officers assigned to the FA 50 FA will normally spend 24 to 36 months in a specific position. An officer may spend a
longer period assigned to a geographical area where there is a high concentration of billets such as the National Capital
Region. Force Management officers should seek to diversify the types of jobs they fill if the tour length in a particular
area exceeds three years in order to broaden the scope, skill set, and experiences obtained through repetitive assignments. OCONUS locations will continue to require specific tour lengths.
a. Key Force Management developmental positions. A field grade officer is expected to perform successfully in a
specific FA 50 position to be considered properly experienced in a particular facet of force management. Officers are
encouraged to broaden their individual and professional skills by seeking alternating assignments in positions that vary
both in type and echelon of major headquarters and achieve a balance between strategic and operational levels.
However, it’s important to understand that the value of an assignment is tied more closely to the skills and experience
gained at each rank versus the specific position an officer holds.
b. Force Management FA life cycle. Figure 31–1, below, depicts a Force Management FA life cycle and the range
of developmental assignments within the FA.

282

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

Figure 31–1. FA 50 Active Army Developmental Model

31–6. Requirements, authorizations, and inventory
a. Goal. The FA 50 goal is to have a field grade officer mix of Force Management authorizations that provide
challenging assignments for professional development while maintaining an inventory of officers that enables each
Force Management officer to be competitive for promotion at rates that meet or exceed Army averages.
b. OPMS re-design and evolution. The number of FA 50 authorizations, by grade, will vary as force structure
decisions are made and actions to implement them are taken. Officers desiring more information on current authorizations or inventory should contact either the FA 50 proponency office or the FA 50 assignments officer at AHRC.
31–7. Key officer life cycle initiatives for Force Management officers
a. Structure. Officers serve primarily on Army, Joint, or DOD staffs and in their field operating activities, in
dedicated organizations (for example, Force Design Directorate, TRADOC combat developments, and so on). Force
Management officers have an equally important role as part of the warfighting team within the ASCC, corps, and
division levels serving as the primary advisor to the commander on issues relating to force management, structure, and
synchronizing requirements with solutions.
b. Acquire. There are two points in an officer’s career when the officer may acquire the FA 50 designation. The first
is a result of the FDB that may come as late as the officer’s selection for promotion to major. The second is later in the
officer’s career pattern depending on their performance of duty. The criteria for selecting an officer during the FD
process includes needs of the Army, officer preference, commander’s input (OER), undergraduate degree, and graduate

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

283

degree. Prior training and experience in force management as a captain does not guarantee selection to the FA 50 FA at
the time of FD, but may enhance the officer’s chances of being designated into the CF.
c. Distribute. The FA 50 assignments officer within AHRC OPMD, and the FA 50 assignments officer at the
Colonels Management Office (CMO), SLD Office, HQDA, both manage FA 50 officer assignments. Assignment to FA
50 authorized positions, to ACS, fellowships, or to branch/FA developmental positions depends upon the needs of the
Army, officer preference, and officer competencies at the time of assignment.
d. Deploy. FA 50 officers can be deployed worldwide at any time. FA 50 officers may deploy with their units in the
course of normal operations, or as individuals to support Joint and multinational operations when their special expertise
is called for across the range of military operations.
e. Sustain. Officers designated into the operations support functional category compete for promotions with other
operations support officers for lieutenant colonel and colonel promotions. The FA 50 assignments officers in CMD and
CMO monitor the officers’ careers, and the FA 50 proponency office provides the directive policies for the FA.
f. Develop. Officers develop their force management skills through a series of progressively more difficult assignments and supporting assignment oriented training that provides the officer an opportunity to apply his or her skills to a
wide range of Army and DOD problems. Additional development of the officer occurs through Service in branch and
FA developmental positions. In these developmental positions, officers are exposed to varied Army organizations and
functions while allowing FA 50 officers the ability to hone their skills. Development also includes ACS for completion
of a master’s level degree and a Fellowship with RAND Arroyo Center. Officers should complete a master’s degree in
a primary or associate discipline (refer to tables 31–2 and 31–3) prior to consideration for the RAND Fellowship.
g. Separate. FA 50 officers separate from the Army in accordance with applicable regulatory guidance.
31–8. Reserve Component Force Management officers
a. General. RC Force Management officers in the AGR) program in an active status may serve the same role and
mission as their Active Army) counterparts. Officers in a reserve status perform similar but not identical roles
dependent upon the type and level of the organizations they support. The unique nature of the reserve status RC
officers’ roles as citizen Soldiers poses challenges for professional development. Despite these challenges, RC officers
are expected to follow Active Army officer development patterns as closely as possible, with the exception that RC
officers have increased windows to complete mandatory educational requirements. To meet professional development
objectives, RC officers in a reserve status (ARNG and USAR) must be willing to, whenever feasible, rotate among
TPUs, IRR, and IMA programs both within and outside of their respective components. AGR professional development
assignments are managed separately by each component’s full-time support branch. Geographical considerations, as
well as the need to provide as many officers as possible the opportunity to serve with troops in leadership and staff
positions necessitate these transfers. Every attempt will be made to assign RC Force Management officers in developmental positions, but opportunities are limited. Unlike their Active Army counterparts, RC Force Management officers
may have to revert to basic branch assignments to continue their reserve participation and career development. For
guidance on RC officer development, see chapter 7.
b. Assignment opportunities. RC Force Management officers can expect assignment opportunities that mirror those
of Active Army officers, as well as positions applicable exclusively to the RC. RC FA 50 officers serve at all levels
within the DOD, and consequently must fully understand and be conversant with the roles, missions and composition
of the RC as an integral component of the total Army. The success of a RC Force Management officer is not measured
by length of Service in any one component or control group, but by the officer’s breadth of experience, duty
performance, and adherence to FA requirements. Assignments in FA 50 are available throughout the RC (AGR, TPU,
and IMA).
c. Qualification and professional development. RC Force Management officers satisfy FA qualification requirements
and become competitive for promotion when they attend military schools and then seek assignments in positions of
increased responsibility.
(1) Qualification. Requirements for qualification depend upon component and status. For RC officers of the USAR
in the AGR program, qualification requirements are the same as for Active Army FA 50 officers and are outlined
above in paragraph 31–3b. For ARNG officers in a reserve status, constructive credit may be used to award the FA 50
AOC. Constructive credit consideration requirements are—
(a) Have completed the Advanced Force Management Course (4 week).
(b) Have completed the Army National Guard Force Management Course (2 week).
(c) Have accumulated two of the past five years of Force Development/Force Integration experience.
(d) Receive endorsement from the Director, Force Management (NGB–ARF) Requests for constructive credit award
of FA 50 AOC can be made through NGB–ARF to the FA 50 proponent office.
(2) Professional development. The following standards listed below must be met in order to prepare RC officers to
be considered qualified for promotion to the next higher rank unless otherwise noted (length of Service in a given
position should not be narrowly construed; key is assignment diversity, level of participation, diverse experiences, and
skill set and sufficient time within each assignment to develop competence; USAR AGR officers will be single tracked
to the extent possible)—

284

(a) Captain. There are no FA requirements for captains; however, captains have the opportunity to attend the initial
SI 3R producing force management training AFMC and serve in 3R-coded positions once they have completed any
basic branch requirements and schooling.
(b) Major.
1. Majors will successfully complete the CCC and common core ILE course,
2. Serve successfully in a 50A coded position, with optimally qualified officers serving for 24 or more months in
such a position.
3. Complete the four-week AFMC. Further professional development opportunities include the 14-week FA 50 QC
and ACS/TWI fellowships.

(c) Lieutenant colonel.

2. Serve a successfully in a lieutenant colonel grade level Force Management position. Optimally qualified officers

at HQDA, OCAR, Joint staff, or USARC Staff. Civilian Force Management Service such as time spent as a career
program (CP) 26 series, Manpower and Force Management, employee will be taken into consideration. Civilian Force
Management Service must be annotated on the biography submitted to promotion boards.
(d) Colonel.
1. Successfully complete ILE and the AFMC.
2. Serve successfully in at least one 50A coded position. Optimally qualified officers will have served 48 months in
50A positions of which they should serve 12 months in an O5 50A position and 12 months in an O6 50A position. As
senior force managers, colonels serve in assignments that require both technical Force Management and managerial
skills. They should be able to oversee and direct diverse force management efforts. They should pursue an advanced
civilian degree, completion of resident SSC, and potential senior level fellowships.
3. Certain jobs in for Army Reserve AGR officers are critical for career progression. At the O4 level, OCAR
organizational integrator is considered the equivalent of battalion XO or battalion S3 positions. At the O5 level,
division chief, branch chief, or deputy director of force programs are considered battalion command equivalent
positions. At the O6 level, the director of force programs is considered a brigade command equivalent position.

below.

they don’t possess FA 50 qualifications. These officers are strongly encouraged to apply for FA 50. The FA 50
proponency office through AHRC–St. Louis will be the approval authority for all requests. Civilian Force Management
assignments will be considered as developmental equivalents when qualifying these officers for positions of increased
responsibility.
f. RC training participation and credit. See chapter 7.
