35–8. The Logistics Branch
LG Branch officers are examples of Army pentathletes. They are builders of leaders and teams. They are competent,
full-spectrum professionals who support the Soldier. LG officers are effective in managing, leading, and changing large
organizations. They are skilled in governance, statesmanship, and diplomacy. A logistician understands cultural context
and works effectively across it. They are part of a Joint team, have an expeditionary outlook, and can think for
themselves in unpredictable situations. They are adaptive, trained and ready, physically fit, and are comfortable
working in JIIM environments. LG officers are self-reliant, proactive leaders who work in asymmetric and unpredictable environments where time available for problem analysis is likely constrained, but where sound, timely decisions are
urgent.
a. Unique purpose of the LG Branch. The purpose of the LG Branch is to merge all logistics basic branch officers
(Ordnance, Quartermaster, Transportation) upon completion of the combined LG CCC into one unified branch in order
to create logistics pentathletes, focused on being, primarily, multifunctional logisticians, capable of planning, integrating, and directing sustainment activities that will enable Army forces to initiate and sustain full spectrum operations.
b. Unique functions of the LG Branch. LG Branch officers serve in both operating and generating force structures
and require extensive experience in integrating 6 out of 12 sustainment functions (see FM 3–0); supply, field services,
transportation, maintenance, explosive ordnance disposal, and force health protection. LG officers should also be
familiar with the other six functions; human resources support, financial management, legal support, general engineering, religious support, and band support. LG officers may be called upon to handle more functions as further changes
are made to the Army modular force and generate additional JIIM requirements.
c. Unique features of work in the LG Branch. At the company-grade level, logistics officer assignments will be
fairly evenly split between multifunctional and functional. As officers progress from company grade to field grade,
assignments grow increasingly multifunctional. Officers must develop and use a diverse set of skills as they move
between functional and multifunctional assignments in the operating and generating force. LG Branch officers work at
all levels of command and staff and perform the following functions and tasks:
(1) Command, direct, and control multifunctional and functional logistics units.
(2) Provide for coordination of logistics activities at all levels of command.
(3) Coordinate logistics for JIIM operations.
(4) Develop logistics doctrine, organizations, and equipment.
(5) Instruct both multifunctional and functional logistics skills at Service schools and colleges.
(6) Serve in positions, such as staff officers in brigade support battalions (BSB), sustainment brigades, combat
sustainment support battalion (CSSB), expeditionary sustainment commands (ESC), theater sustainment commands
(TSC), Joint task force headquarters (JTFHQ), division/corps/ASCC headquarters, and combatant commander
(COCOM) headquarters.

344

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

(7) Active Army officers may serve as logistics advisors to ARNG and USAR organizations. Required officer
characteristics (skills, knowledge, and attributes).
d. Competencies and actions. Mission success ultimately requires the proper balance between technical skills and
the ability to understand and apply the appropriate tactical skills at the right moment. Success also requires honed
conceptual skills, enabling officers to handle changing situations and ideas. Officers must be trained how to think, not
what to think. The constantly changing nature of modern warfare requires agile logistics forces and logistics officers.
Responsiveness, flexibility, and economy are key logistics principles that enable officers to lead units to support an
agile combat force and execute operations more swiftly than their opponents.
(1) Responsiveness. Responsiveness is providing the right support in the right place, at the right time, and it includes
the ability to foresee operational requirements. Responsiveness involves identifying, accumulating, and maintaining the
minimum assets, capabilities, and information necessary to meet support requirements. Responsiveness involves the
ability to meet changing requirements on short notice. Anticipating those requirements is critical to providing responsive logistics.
(2) Flexibility. Flexibility is the ability to adapt logistics structures and procedures to changing situations, missions,
and concepts of operations. LG plans, operations, and organizations must be flexible enough to achieve both responsiveness and economy. LG organizations provide support in any environment throughout the spectrum of conflict and
adapts as operations evolve. Flexibility may require improvisation (inventing, arranging, or fabricating what is needed
from what is on hand). When established procedures do not provide the required support, logistics personnel seek
innovative solutions, rapidly devise new procedures, or take extraordinary measures to adapt to the situation.
(3) Economy. Economy means providing the most efficient support to accomplish the mission. Resources are always
limited. The commander achieves economy by prioritizing and allocating resources. Many logistics developments focus
on the ability of the logistics commander to provide required support with the minimum expenditure of resources.
e. Unique skills. The Logistics officer Corps contains ten AOCs and one skill identifier. Training for these AOCs
and skills is open to all male and female LG Branch officers. The numerical designation of some of the secondary
AOCs coincides with the other LG corps branches/regiments. LG Branch officers all have a common, primary AOC,
90A. Refer to the other branch sections of this chapter for a more detailed description of the types of functional units
and staff jobs as well as the criteria for obtaining each of the other AOCs. These skills are gained and developed
through multiple operational assignments and continuous professional study and self-development.
(1) Logistician (AOC 90A). This is the primary AOC for the LG Branch. Officers holding this AOC will command
and control multifunctional logistics units as well as serve in various multifunctional logistics staff positions. All
officers will receive this designation as their primary AOC once they graduate from CLC3. Medical Service Corps
officers who attend CLC3 will receive the 90A designation as a secondary AOC, and with that AOC will have
opportunities to serve in multifunctional logistics units on staff, as well as be eligible to compete for command of
multifunctional logistics units.
(2) Transportation general (AOC 88A). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG Branch. Officers holding
this AOC will command and control transportation units as well as serve in varied levels of transportation staff
positions.
(3) Traffic management (AOC 88B). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG Branch. Officers holding this
skill serve on division or higher staffs/commands at the operational or strategic level in order to provide specialized
knowledge of transportation organizations, equipment, and doctrine. Officers will plan, coordinate, and synchronize the
rapid deployment, RSO&I, sustainment/distribution management and redeployment of forces in any area of operations.
(4) Marine and terminal operations (AOC 88C). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG Branch. Officers
holding this AOC will command and control marine and terminal transportation units as well as serve in varied levels
of transportation staff positions.
(5) Motor/rail transportation (AOC 88D). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG Branch. Officers holding
this AOC will command and control motor and rail transportation units as well as serve in varied levels of transportation staff positions.
(6) EOD (AOC 89E). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG Branch. Officers holding this AOC will
command and control EOD units as well as serve in varied levels of EOD staff positions.
(7) Materiel maintenance and munitions management (AOC 91A). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG
Branch. Officers holding this AOC will command and control maintenance or ammunition units as well as serve in
varied levels of ordnance staff positions.
(8) Supply and materiel management (AOC 92A). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG Branch. Officers
holding this AOC will command and control quartermaster units as well as serve in varied levels of quartermaster staff
positions.
(9) Aerial delivery and materiel (AOC 92D). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG Branch. Officers
holding this AOC will command and control aerial delivery and materiel units as well as serve in varied levels of aerial
delivery staff positions.
(10) Petroleum and water (AOC 92F). This is one of nine secondary AOCs for the LG Branch. Officers holding this

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

345

AOC will command and control petroleum and water units as well as serve in varied levels of petroleum staff
positions.
(11) Mortuary affairs (SI 4V). This is the only skill identifier for the LG Branch. Officers holding this skill manage
mortuary affairs support, both on staff and as commanders.
f. Unique knowledge. LG officers must know how to exploit the following aspects of the agile logistics force when
planning and executing operations; modular unit designs, force tailoring, and split based operations. LG officers must
know sustainment unit capabilities and how units are employed in order to provide relevant sustainment information to
the commander in terms he/she can rapidly apply to the situation, enabling him to visualize, describe, and direct
operations. LG officers must be able to translate information on status and location of resources into the impact on
combat effectiveness in the present and near future using emerging information technology. LG officers should be
grounded in all sustainment Standard Army Management Information Systems (STAMIS) and C2 Systems, such as the
Battle Command Sustainment and Support System (BCS3), Movement Tracking System (MTS), and Global Combat
Support System-Army (GCSS–A). This knowledge includes practical experience in tactics and combined arms operations at the tactical, operational, and strategic levels as well as deployment operations. Logisticians must be comfortable working in fluid, nonlinear, noncontiguous environments with highly distributed forces functioning continually, at
various tempos, and in various phases of military operations. Additionally, logisticians must understand the concepts
and employment of Joint logistics in order to provide support to the combatant commander wherever the force is
located.
g. Unique attributes. LG officers require sound judgment as well as the ability to think creatively and reason
analytically, critically, and ethically. The dynamics associated with training logistics units and supporting operational
missions across the full spectrum require a sense of ingenuity and foresight. LG officers must fully embrace the
Warrior Ethos, be confident in their abilities and training, competent in their area of expertise, ready and adaptable to
change, levelheaded under pressure, and have a Joint and expeditionary mindset. They must be innovative and
comfortable working with complex, information technologies.
35–9. Logistics Branch qualification and development
The goal of the professional development of multifunctional logistics officers is to produce and sustain highly qualified
tactically and operationally oriented individuals to provide seamless logistical support in combat and other missions.
LG officers should expect to be assigned to a wide variety of units and organizations. LG Branch positions (coded 90A
on authorization documents) provide the required experience and development in order to gain proficiency as a LG
Branch officer. They are only found at the captain and above experience level. Officers may use the LG Branch life
cycle development and utilization model (see fig 35–16, below) as a guideline for monitoring their career paths. The
LG Branch model provides progressive career development through challenging command and staff assignments in
logistics management and leader development. Assignment patterns will vary depending on the needs of the Army,
professional development requirements, manning guidance, and individual officer preferences. Logisticians can expect
to fill key positions in JIIM organizations. Officers should also expect to serve in functional logistics assignments
based on their secondary AOC qualifications or their skill identifiers as stated in paragraph 35–8b, above. See other
branch sections in this chapter for details on those types of assignments.

346

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

Figure 35–16. Active Army LG Corps Developmental Model

a. Captain.
(1) Education. Officers generally attend the CLC3 at their 3rd-4th YOS. Attendance to CLC3 will be TDY and return
or PCS as fits the needs of the Army and follow-on assignments. Officers receive initial instruction in multifunctional
logistics, instruction on commanding at the company level, and advanced technical instruction in their original
accessions branch. The original accessions branch will become the officer’s secondary AOC and will dictate functional
assignments unless the officer elects to change his/her designated AOC. Logisticians may change their AOC by
attending qualification courses following completion of CLC3. For example, an officer of the Transportation or
Ordnance regiment could attend the Petroleum Officer’s Course after CLC3, and thus gain the 92F AOC, and thereafter
be affiliated with the Quartermaster regiment. LG Branch officers will only have one designated secondary AOC.
Though not mandatory for promotion, there are additional educational opportunities captains normally pursue during
their 4th-10th YOS that enhance and broaden an officer’s understanding of multifunctional logistics, which are as
follows:
(a) SOC.
(b) TWI
(c) Complete an advanced degree in a logistics discipline.
(d) The LEDC helps to prepare officers for multifunctional duties across the spectrum of operations. For a select
number of officers, attendance to LEDC may be coupled with a cooperative degree program pursuing an advanced
degree in logistics from the FIT.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

347

(e) Additional courses to obtain other LG Branch AOCs or SIs.
(2) FA process. Between their 4th-7th YOS, officers have the option of pursuing one of many different FAs required
by the Army For example, many logistics officers apply to the Acquisition Corps (FA 51). If accepted into this
program, officers attend numerous qualification courses and have specific developmental paths for future assignments.
However, once officers are accepted into another FA designation, such as FA 51, they will not return to the LG Branch
nor will they be eligible to command logistics units.
(3) Key developmental experiences. After graduation from CLC3, captains can expect functional and multifunctional
logistics assignments as company commanders and battalion and brigade staff officers as well as other staff positions in
the operating and generating force. Company command is not required for promotion to major, but is a key
developmental (KD) experience that will enhance an officer’s chance for command of a logistics unit at higher levels.
Officers who desire to be competitive for logistics battalion command should strive to serve as logistics company
commanders. The type of logistics company commanded may or may not dictate the type of battalion they could
command.
b. Major.
(1) Education. majors must complete ILE which includes the core course and the Advanced Operations and
Warfighting Course at Fort Leavenworth, as well as specified logistics electives. Completion of ILE will make officers
ILE and JPME I qualified. Attendance at ILE will be an assignment process, not by board selection, and will normally
occur between the 8th and 12th year of commissioned Service.
(2) KD experiences. Majors are primarily staff officers, serving in positions at all levels. They must demonstrate
their abilities to manage multifunctional organizations and various logistics missions. They build on their skills and
experiences from their captain years, have assignments of greater complexity, and prepare themselves to be battalion
commanders. An officer’s performance during these assignments demonstrates a mastery of skills, knowledge, and
attributes. Majors should focus on gaining experiences at the tactical level by serving as battalion support operations
officers, battalion XOs, or battalion operations officers (S2/3) of support battalions and brigade S4s of brigade combat
teams. Although no particular one of the above staff jobs are mandatory to hold for promotion to lieutenant colonel,
they are key experiences that will make majors competitive for battalion command once they have made lieutenant
colonel.
c. Lieutenant colonel. This grade requires a higher level of supervisory and managerial skills. LG Branch officers
are responsible for integrating and synchronizing logistics operations and influencing and developing policy as it relates
to logistics management. In addition, LG Branch lieutenant colonels are responsible for providing more comprehensive
supervisory control of subordinate LG Corps officers.
(1) Education. Lieutenant colonels wanting to remain competitive for subsequent promotion should be selected to a
SSC, either resident or non-resident. All officers are also encouraged to obtain a graduate-level education in an
appropriate discipline.
(2) KD experiences. Developmental experience gained as a lieutenant colonel provides the Army with officers in
senior grades who have developed the expertise needed both multi-functionally and functionally. Lieutenant colonels
serve primarily in key staff and/or Joint positions in sustainment brigade headquarters, sustainment commands (expeditionary), sustainment commands (theater), division, corps, and higher staffs. Selected lieutenant colonels will have the
opportunity to command battalions. Successful battalion command, while not mandatory for promotion to colonel, will
enhance the officer’s potential for brigade command.
d. Colonel. LG Branch colonels command at the brigade level and hold the senior logistics positions on division,
corps, sustainment commands, and many HQDA, JCS, and DOD staffs.
(1) Education. Although no specific mandatory military education requirement exists for colonels, attendance at a
SSC or completion of the AWC Distance Education Course identifies those officers with exceptional promotion
potential for Service in positions of increased responsibility at the next higher grade. All officers are also encouraged to
obtain a graduate-level education in an appropriate discipline.
(2) KD experiences. Experiences at the colonel level are primarily operational and strategic-level staff assignments.
Currently, commands make up only 21 percent of colonel-level positions. Joint assignments are viewed as key for
career enhancement, as well as important to the Army.
e. Self-development. Self-development is the responsibility of every officer and ranges from professional reading
during off-duty time to aggressively seeking out positions of increased responsibility. Each officer, with support from
mentors, should develop career goals and clearly articulate those goals to the commander and assignments officer at the
AHRC. Always remember that an officer is his or her own best career manager. By actively participating in the
management of career decisions, officers will improve the likelihood of a successful career. Officers are encouraged to
continue to broaden their logistics experience by doing the following:
(1) Establish a professional reading program.
(2) Participate in their regimental association.
(3) Participate in civilian professional logistics organizations.
(4) Become a certified professional logistician (CPL).
(5) Obtain a civilian degree in logistics-related fields.

348

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

(6) Complete logistics-related correspondence courses.
(7) Complete courses in Joint logistics at ALMC.
(8) Conduct research and write articles for professional logistics publications.
35–10. Logistics Branch Reserve Component officers
a. General. RC LG Branch officer development and qualifications parallel those of their Active Duty counterparts as
described in paragraphs 35–8 and 35–9., above. Life cycle development and utilization also parallel the Active Army as
shown in figure 35–16, below. Training and development of RC LG Branch officers may be more challenging than for
their Active Army counterparts, due to several constraints, such as time to train, state and Federal missions, geographical location, decentralized officer management, and ongoing transformation of units. With the incorporation of the LG
Branch, RC officers must recognize these challenges in order to overcome them, and become equally qualified as their
Active Army counterparts.
b. LG Branch qualification and development. RC officer will be inducted into the LG Branch upon completion of a
logistics (Ordnance, Quartermaster, Transportation) RC CCC* (see interim implementation guidance at the end of this
para). Officers will hold 90A as their primary AOC and a secondary AOC out of table 35–1, above. This policy applies
to the following officers; AGR, TPU, M–Day, IMA, and IRR. As is the case with Active Army officers, there will be
no lieutenants (nor non-CCC graduates) in the LG Branch. RC Medical Service Corps (MFA70) may obtain 90A as a
secondary AOC.
(1) Captain. captains are either company commanders or staff officers. Officers will have LG Branch assignments
according to organizational structures within their geographical location/state boundaries. Officers should take full
advantage of the Battle Command Knowledge System–LOGNet and the CASCOM sustainment portal to keep skills
current in the LG Branch. Officers are encouraged to take additional multifunctional logistics courses when resources
permit.
(2) Major. majors are primarily staff officers, serving in positions at all levels. They must demonstrate their abilities
to manage assets in multifunctional organizations and organize various logistics missions. They build on their skills and
experiences from their captain years, have assignments of greater complexity, and prepare themselves to be battalion
commanders. Accordingly, it is highly encouraged that majors attend additional training courses to further their
proficiency in multifunctional logistics. Available training courses include SOC, RCMCSS, LEDC, or ALEDC.
(3) Lieutenant colonel and colonel. lieutenant colonels and colonels are the refinement stages of an RC officer’s
career. Officers will be expected to mentor junior officers on the importance of maintaining LG Branch proficiency
through multiple experiences and encourage officers to obtain additional multifunctional training when appropriate.
Focus is also placed on an officer successfully completing lieutenant colonel- or colonel-level command as well as
serving in senior logistics officer staff positions. Officers are to complete the PCC at Fort Lee, VA, when selected for
lieutenant colonel- or colonel-level command. Officers are encouraged to complete SSC, the same as their Active Army
counterparts.
c. Branch transfer. Officers may branch transfer into the LG Branch at any rank from captain through colonel. The
following rules apply:
(1) Captains who have not yet attended a RC CCC. Officers who choose to transfer into the LG Branch prior to
attending a RC CCC need only attend a logistics (Ordnance, Quartermaster, Transportation) RC CCC*. This course
provides the requisite functional and multifunctional training for LG Branch officers.
(2) Captains and above who have already completed a RC CCC other than logistics. Officers who branch transfer
after attendance at a non-logistics RC CCC must complete the following requirements in any order.
(a) Hold a functional logistics area of concentration from the Ordnance, Quartermaster, or Transportation Branches,
by completion of appropriate online or resident branch transition courses.
(b) Attend one of the following courses; SOC, RCMCSS, LEDC, ALEDC Phase I, or CLC3 (or CLOAC).
(3) It is not the intent to have branch transfer officers change branches twice; they must simply complete the
appropriate transition course that awards a logistics area of concentration as one of the prerequisites to transferring into
the LG Branch. There is no branch transfer into the Ordnance, Quartermaster or Transportation branches at captain or
above, as the only branch available to LG officers at captain or above is the LG Branch.
(4) To apply for the designation of LG Branch, USAR and ARNG officers should forward applications in accordance with published command guidance to their state Adjutant General, AHRC-St. Louis, Army Reserve Active Duty
Management Directorate (ARADMD) or the USAR Command, as appropriate.
35–11. Logistics Corps officer requirements, assignments, and life cycle initiatives
a. Requirements, authorizations, and inventory. The goal is to maintain a healthy, viable career path for all LG
Corps officers. To do this, the field-grade inventory must be optimized in order to meet branch authorizations, provide
sufficient flexibility to support branch generalist positions, and provide officers with a sufficient amount of functional
experience in order to fill functional logistics positions.
b. Preferences. Assignments are based on needs of the Army, professional development requirements, and officer
preference. Officers assigned to life cycle units can expect 3-year tours. LG Corps officers can expect to serve in

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

349

branch generalist (01A coded) assignments and/or commands. Assignments are managed by the Force Sustainment
Division of AHRC Officer Personnel Management Directorate.
c. Precedence. Assignment to KD positions will have precedence, although there is flexibility on the sequence of
assignments Stabilization policies and local commanders may influence assignment precedence. Assignments will be
either to a LG Branch position or to the officers chosen secondary AOC with no precedence of one over the other.
d. Joint assignments. LG Corps officers can expect to be considered for Joint duty assignments worldwide. Joint
experience is important to the Army and is essential to individual officers for their advancement into senior leadership
positions. Joint is the way to fight and Joint assignments and education are interwoven into the fabric of Army officer
development.
e. Branch generalist assignments. LG Corps officers should expect to be assigned at least once to a branch
generalist assignment. These positions may or may not relate directly to their technical expertise, but are important to
the Army. Criteria for selection include overall manner of performance, military experience, military and civilian
education, and demonstrated potential to serve in positions of increased responsibility. These positions include, but are
not limited to, the following:
(1) Multifunctional staff positions at the grade of major and above.
(2) Advisory groups in foreign countries.
(3) Inspector general (IG) office.
(4) U.S. Army Recruiting Command (USAREC) staff.
(5) Reserve Officers’ Training Corps (ROTC).
(6) USAR and ARNG liaison.
(7) USMA faculty and staff.
(8) Other executive staff positions.
(9) Service school instructors.
f. Other assignments. LG Corps officers may be assigned to organizations and duties beyond those indicated above.
These other assignments may include White House Fellows, duty with the National Security Council, United Nations,
and other international staffs as well as allied Service schools. The spectrum of possible assignments is large and these
assignments can be characterized as highly responsible and important and require mature, skilled, and well-grounded
officers. Normally officers must be nominated for these types of positions.
g. Duration of critical officer life cycle assignments. At each grade, the amount of time spent in KD assignments
must be monitored to ensure that officer professional development is optimized. Twelve to 24 months in each position
is preferred although not required due to the unpredictability of life cycle manning and stabilization policies. The
important factor is that each selected officer performs to a high standard and is successful in manner of performance.
The new Army force stabilization manning policies will influence LG Corps officers’ developmental experiences.
h. Structure. LG Corps officers serve at all echelons worldwide. Transformation of logistics units into modular
structures is nearly complete. Positions for the three basic branches (Ordnance, Quartermaster, Transportation) are
found at the grade of lieutenant through colonel. Currently, LG branch authorizations are only found at the grade of
captain and above.
i. Acquire. Officers will be accessed into the Ordnance, Quartermaster or Transportation branches through the
USMA, ROTC, or Officer Candidate School. Accessions are based on the needs of the Army and officer preference.
Officers will be inducted from these three branches into the LG Branch upon graduation from CLC3. Currently, LG
Corps officers are not able to participate in the Branch Detail Program. The LG Branch will accept officers transferring
from other branches or services on a case-by-case basis, based on the needs of the Army. These officers must attend
CLC3 in order to qualify them as LG Branch officers and a functional branch course in order to gain their secondary
AOC.
j. Distribute. Officers will continue to rotate between operating and generating force assignments. Sequencing and
timing of assignments will be driven by Army requirements and the force stabilization system. Officers should expect
to serve primarily in LG Branch assignments. Secondary AOC developmental assignments will be made as required
meeting the needs of the Army and maintaining the officer’s expertise in that area; however, officers should not expect
back-to-back functional assignments. Officers who select a FA in another functional category will no longer serve in
Logistics Corps assignments.
k. Deploy. LG Branch officers are warfighters who remain personally and professionally prepared to deploy
worldwide at all times. Whether assigned to deployable TOE units or generating force organizations, readiness is
imperative to success of the mission. Officers must prepare themselves and their Families for planned and no notice
deployments throughout an officers’ career.
l. Sustain. There are three major factors that affect officer career development life cycle.
(1) Promotion. LG Branch officers will compete for promotion within the force sustainment functional category.
Promotion rates will be determined by Army needs/DOPMA goals.
(2) Command. LG Branch officers will continue to be centrally selected for command positions at the lieutenant
colonel and colonel level. Command categories include; operations, strategic support, recruiting and training, and

350

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

installation. LG commands are further organized into multifunctional and functional sub-categories. Officers have the
option of selecting the category or categories in which they desire to compete for command while declining competition in other categories. The results of the command selection process are published in the CSL.
(3) OER. The OER will reinforce the linkage between officer development and promotion potential. Starting with
captain reports, the rater and senior rater will recommend the rated officer for the functional category which best suits
the officer’s abilities and interests.
m. Develop. Officer development will continue to occur through a methodical sequence of progressive assignments
in troop units, staff assignments, and institutional training assignments. Self-development continues to be an essential
component of officer development. The goal is to develop and sustain logistics officers fully versed in multifunctional
logistics and experts in one secondary area of expertise (secondary AOC).
n. Separate. Army separation procedures remain in accordance with AR 600–8–24, with exceptions for stop loss/
stop move.
35–12. Life cycle initiatives for Logistics Corps warrant officers
a. Structure. LG Corps WOs serve at all echelons worldwide. Transformation of logistics units into modular
structures is nearly complete. There will be changes to the authorizations of those units based on the restructuring and
re-coding initiatives associated with new missions.
b. Acquire. Accessions are based on needs of the Army. WOs will continue to enter into the LG Corps branches
through accessions from Ordnance, Quartermaster, and Transportation enlisted feeder MOSs. Outstanding LG Corps
NCOs who have demonstrated exceptional leadership, tactical, and technical skills are ideal candidates for accession
into the WO specialties. Army policy prohibits enlisted direct appointments to WO.
c. Distribute. WOs will continue to rotate between operating force and generating force units both in CONUS and
OCONUS.
d. Deploy. LG Corps WOs are technicians and leaders who remain personally and professionally prepared to deploy
worldwide at any time. Whether assigned to force structure units with high levels of readiness or force generation
organizations, all WOs must be fully deployable to accomplish the mission across the full spectrum of conflict. WOs
must prepare themselves and their Families for this most challenging life cycle function.
e. Sustain. There are three major factors that affect the WO career development life cycle.
(1) Promotions. WOs will compete for promotion based on needs of the Army.
(2) Assignment. WOs should adhere to their recommended career development pattern to maximize their technical
and tactical expertise and leadership development. This includes assignments at tactical, operational, and strategic level
as well as Joint, national, and in the training base. Solid performance at various levels of assignment is highly desirable
for future advancement.
(3) OER. The OER will reinforce the linkage between officer development and personnel management. Starting with
WO1, the rater and senior rater will recommend the rated officer for the career development which best suits the
Army’s needs and the WO’s abilities and interests.
f. Develop. WOs develop their knowledge through institutional training and improve their knowledge through
progressive levels of assignments within their specialty at all levels from tactical to national. Self-development
continues to be an essential component of WO development as well as resident training in TASS. The goal is to
professionally develop LG Corps WOs to support Army missions across the full spectrum of operations.
g. Separate. Army separation procedures remain in accordance with AR 600–8–24, with exceptions for stop loss/
stop move.

Chapter 36
Human Resources Area of Concentration
36–1. History
The Army G–1 approved merging AG Branch, personnel systems management, and FA 43A, Human Resources (HR)
management populations into a single officer area of concentration (AOC) HR officer, 42B/42H. Even though the
official consolidation does not take place until Oct 08 (fiscal year 09), the assignment process and interchangeable use
of both branch 42 and FA 43 officers is happening today. The primary goal of the merger is to provide the most
effective professional HR support to the modular Army possible, while ensuring that the majority of officers in both
specialties are not disadvantaged. Significant time, coordination, and effort led to this G–1 directed merger to
encompass successful accessions, training, reclassification, assignments, promotions, and schooling opportunities. G–1
has established a plan to ensure that the Army’s HR officer corps provides the best trained HR professional leadership
possible to serve in the expeditionary and modular Army.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

351

36–2. Unique features of the Human Resources area of concentration
a. Unique purpose of HR AOC. The purpose of the HR AOC is to provide activities and functions to sustain human
resource functions of manning the force, providing HR services, and personnel support to Soldiers, DA civilians,
Families, contractors, retirees, veterans, and organizations providing support to operations within the commander’s
intent. HR officers manage functions from the HR life cycle that include personnel procurement, training, professional
development, distribution, sustainment, retirement or separation, and help ensure a quality force. These functions are
performed under the human resource umbrella of the Army G–1 and are described in Field Manual 1–0.
(1) Man the Force—
(a) Personnel readiness management.
(b) Reception, replacement, return to duty, rest & recuperation (R&R), redeployment (R5) operations.
(c) Personnel information management.
(d) Personnel accounting/strength reporting.
(2) Provide personnel services—
(a) Essential personnel services (EPS).
(b) Casualty operations management.
(3) Provide personnel support—
(a) Postal operations.
(b) MWR & community support activities.
(c) Band support.
(4) HR planning and operations.
b. The way ahead. The HR AOC continues to transform to meet the Army’s Campaign Plans and Army G–1
Personnel Transformation Plan. HR officers of the future will be well versed and cross-trained in multiple technical
systems supporting the Soldier throughout full spectrum operations. Officers must be computer literate and able to
quickly grasp information, analyze data, and provide immediate output of data to Commanders for use within the
operational setting. The development of Human Resource Officers will also focus on the development of agile and
adaptive officers and multi-skilled leaders who collectively embody knowledge of JIIM organizations. While Human
Resources Command will make every effort to synchronize the three priorities, the needs of the Army and the
professional development needs of the officer must continue to take precedence over individual preference. The
assignment of HR officers will continue to be made based on—
(1) The needs of the Army.
(2) The professional development needs of the officer.
(3) The officer’s preference.
c. Unique functions performed by the HR AOC. The HR AOC provides manpower, HR services, and personnel
support to commanders at all echelons in order to enhance the readiness and operational capabilities of the total force
and ensure success across the full spectrum of military operations, and formulates policy and directs the Army’s
military personnel system at strategic, operational, and tactical levels. This includes the critical operational/tactical
personnel systems/functions outlined in FMs 1–0, 3–0, and 4–0. HR AOC officers serve at all levels of the Army and
throughout the Joint community. The HR AOC is a staff-centric AOC where HR officers (BR 42B lieutenants and
captains) serve as battalion S–1s and brigade strength managers and senior HR officers (AOC 42H majors, lieutenant
colonels, colonels) serve as brigade/BCT S–1s, division, corps, ASCC/Army G–1s, serving as the primary advisors to
commanders on all matters related to human resources. Senior HR officers serve as the HR support operations officer
in sustainment structures and serve as operations officers, team leaders, and division chiefs in the Human Resource
Sustainment Center (HRSC). Senior HR officers also serve in Joint positions providing human resource expertise and
guidance for Joint commanders. Senior HR officers serve as equal opportunity officers and command HR Companies,
reception battalions, brigade special troops battalions, combat sustainment support battalions, military entrance processing stations, recruiting companies and battalions, garrisons, and Army Bands commands. They train military and
civilian personnel in personnel administration and military human resource management and develop HR doctrine to
support the full spectrum of operations. HR WOs serve at all levels of the Army. They serve in Army bands, brigade/
BCT S–1s and division, corps, ASCC/Army, ACOM G–1s, the DA staff, SRC12 HR structures, the Adjutant General’s
School, and the U.S. Army School of Music. They train military and civilian personnel in organizational management
and HR Service support. They develop policy, procedures, and doctrine to support these operations during peace and
war.
d. Unique features of work in the HR AOC. Duty positions associated in the HR AOC require thoroughly trained
and properly developed officers to provide the knowledge of military HR operations, its systems, relationships, and
interfaces. The HR officer may serve in one of the AOC or skills described below.
(1) HR officer (AOC 42B) and senior HR officer (42H). Officers who serve in this branch manage HR core
competencies and functions that support military HR management including policy formulation, interpretation, and
implementation at the brigade/BCT, division/corps, ASCC/Army, HQDA, and within JIIM operations. Example tasks
which are part of the core competencies include R5 operations management, strength management, reassignment,

352

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

sponsorship, and procurement of officer and enlisted personnel; unit manning, leaves and passes, awards and decorations, officer and enlisted transfers, and discharges, casualty operations management, postal operations, and the
planning and tracking of HR operations to support deployed forces. Senior HR and HR officers manage military HR
functions that support military personnel information management, military HR services, and military personnel
automation. Examples are personnel database management, personnel automation, personnel records management,
personnel accounting and strength reporting, casualty operations, officer and NCO evaluation systems, and officer and
enlisted promotion systems, identification documents, reassignment systems, and systems updates.
(2) Army band (AOC 42C). Officers who serve in this AOC plan, develop, and direct activities of military bands and
musical training of Army band members; coordinate all band activities of the command; and conduct technical
inspections and evaluate operational status, technical capability, and proficiency of Army bands.
(3) Postal operations (SI 4J). Officers who hold this SI formulate policies for and direct the activities of units
engaged in postal operations. Individuals must complete the Joint Service Postal Operations Course and/or the Postal
Supervisor’s Course. This SI is only awarded to HR officers.
e. Army HR focus. The Army G–1 provides HR oversight in the HR AOC performance. The Army G–1 is
responsible for all HR management policy, programs, goals, standards, structure, and resources. Included under the
Army G–1 HR umbrella is personnel readiness management. Personnel readiness management is the responsibility of
the HR AOC officer. HR AOC officers serve at all levels in MTOE and TDA organizations. HR AOC officers manage
the distribution, assignment, and personnel strength accounting systems that assure personnel readiness of the force and
they provide HR Service to Soldiers, DOD civilians, contractors, retirees, and Family members. HR AOC officers
supervise postal Service for Soldiers in deployed environments. HR AOC officers are vital members of the commander’s staff, working for the good of the organization.
f. Officer tasks. The information below provides a broad outline of an officer’s mission essential task list. HR AOC
officers must—
(1) Know the organization, structure, and doctrine of the warfighting Army.
(2) Know battlefield concepts of operation and interoperability and dependency of TOE units.
(3) Understand force structure analysis and approval process; manpower and equipment requirements, budget,
authorizations, and organization/mission change policy and programs.
(4) Understand the roles and missions of other services and Joint and multinational human resource and manpower
operations.
(5) Retain competency in the operation and management of existing and emerging military and civilian personnel/
HR systems and doctrine that are critical to success on the battlefield.
(6) Understand and use automation and other new technology that can improve timeliness and efficiency. Army
band officers (42C) must have advanced knowledge of musical performance and conducting techniques, and extensive
training in music history and theory.
g. Assignment opportunities other than MTOE.
(1) Army G–1 staff officer, Division Chief, Deputy Director.
(2) Commander MEPS, AIT company/battalion, recruiting company/battalion or Army School of Music (420C).
(3) S–1, G–1, or J–1.
(4) EO officer.
(5) Branch Chief, AHRC.
(6) Personnel management officer, AHRC.
(7) Operations officer, bandmaster, or staff band officer (420C).
(8) Instructor (USMA or AG School).
36–3. Characteristics required of officers
a. Unique attributes. All officers must be physically and mentally fit, maintain deployability preparedness, maintain
and display self-control, remain calm under pressure, and adhere to published standards and regulations. The Adjutant
General Corps must produce multi-skilled leaders who are critically reflective, comfortable with ambiguity and
uncertainty, and agents of change. HR officers must be challenged and imbued with the confidence to be innovative
and adaptive while competently performing in a JIIM environment.
b. Unique skills.
(1) Tactical and operational. Both technical and operational skills are necessary for success as an HR AOC. The
systems and processes that are used to accomplish HR functions make HR technical skills essential. The understanding
of tactical requirements and the contemporary operating environment is critical in the performance of duty in the full
spectrum operational environment within the standards described by the Warrior Ethos by each officer in the AOC.
(2) Conceptual. HR officers must have conceptual skills that are necessary for strategic vision, critical reasoning,
and problem solving. These officers must be able to move from the abstract concept to concrete solutions in everyday
problems. As principally staff officers, HR AOC officers must be able to conceptualize HR support within the
sustainment construct in support of full spectrum operations.

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

353

(3) Interpersonal. Interpersonal skills are necessary because HR officers must effectively communicate with supported commanders, peers, and other personnel who provide support and Service. These officers must be able to listen,
read, learn, and coordinate actions at all levels. Communications skills, both verbal and written, are critical for HR
officers, especially those serving in S–1 and G–1 positions or on S–1 and G–1 staffs. HR officers must be able to
function effectively as a member of a large coordinating staff.
c. Unique actions.
(1) Decisionmaking. Must be able to demonstrate the ability and willingness to work with others as a team to
achieve operational success. Must be able to frame requirements, analyze data through the decisionmaking process, and
present clear definable options/courses of action to senior leaders
(2) Planning and executing. HR Officers must develop and use a diverse set of skills within the HR planning and
operations core competency to prepare the HR portion of plans and orders and the personnel estimate to ensure HR
providers understand required support to maintain the personnel element of combat power. HR officers must provide
clear and concise directives to Soldiers during the execution of HR mission requirements.
(3) Goal. The goal of the AG branch is to provide each officer with a series of opportunities in order to develop HR
professionals with well rounded backgrounds and an understanding of JIIM operations.
36–4. Critical Active Army officer developmental assignments
a. Officer qualification and development. (Career development model is at fig 36–1, below).

(1) Lieutenant.
(a) After completing the (BOLC, Phase III (proponent institutional training), officers are assigned to a duty position
that will allow maximum exposure to a wide range of HR functions.
(b) The focus of effort during the lieutenant years is to acquire, reinforce, and hone troop leading, technical, tactical,
logistics, and administrative skills. Inculcation of the Warrior Ethos and Army core values is essential in the
development of young officers. Prior to promotion to captain, officers must possess an in-depth knowledge of
combined arms operations gained through on-the-job training. By law, officers must obtain a baccalaureate degree
before promotion to captain. Officers may face initial assignments at installations where they may be a part of a life
cycle brigade combat team (BCT) 36-month assignment and other emerging assignments. Second lieutenants entering
life cycle manned (LCM) units will stay for the unit’s life cycle and fill a number of developing HR, staff-centric
positions. Lieutenants that enter LCM BCTs will most likely serve as a captain battalion S–1, but may serve in a
lieutenant position as a captain. Assignments will be based on—
1. Needs of the Army.
2. Professional development requirements.
3. Officer’s preferences.
(2) Captain.
(a) Officers generally attend the CCC at their 4th YOS that currently corresponds with promotion to captain. CCC
will be TDY and return, TCS, or PCS as determined by the needs of the Army, unit force stabilization or life cycle
stabilization and follow-on assignment. Captains must aggressively prepare for and seek the skills and experience that
will prepare them for duties at the rank of major. Assignments will be based on the needs of the Army, professional
development requirements, and officer’s preferences. Officers can expect operating and generating force assignments
and become fully developed HR captains after the following:
1. Possess bachelor’s degree.
2. Complete CCC.
3. Serve a minimum of 24 months in at least one HR technical/operational assignment.
4. Band officers must complete a minimum of 24 months in any 42C position.
(b) Completion of the CCC and an assignment in any of the positions below is critical in providing the skill base
and experience required of a captain before obtaining the rank of major.
1. Battalion S–1/adjutant.
2. HR plans and operations officer.
3. Assistant HR support operations officer.
4. Brigade/BCT S–1/adjutant.
5. Administrative officer.

7. Division/corps G–1 PASR/PRM officer.
8. Postal officer.
9. 42 coded company/detachment commander.
10. 42 coded operations officer.
11. Staff bands officer, associate bandmaster, and band commander (42C) or company commander at the U.S. Army
School of Music.
(c) Experienced captains will receive developmental assignments that will provide them with exposure to the Army,
and in some cases, Joint organizations. The following are examples of branch generalist professional development
assignments for captains:
1. U.S. Army Recruiting Command/Branch Immaterial Command.

the Foreign Area officer program may assess a limited number of AG officers during the 4th YOS. Designation is
based upon an officer’s desires, qualifications, and needs of the Army. HR officers are encouraged to gain experience
in a variety of assignments within the functionally aligned force sustainment functional category within OPMS. During
functional designation, HR officers may request to remain within AOC 42H or may seek other opportunities within
other FAs. Recommended FAs for HR officers moving outside the force sustainment functional category are public
affairs (FA 46), operations research/systems analysis (FA 49), force management (FA 50), and information systems
management (FA 53). Non-HR officers will enter the HR AOC in the 7th year during the FDB process, and will be
rapidly transitioned into the HR AOC. Military schooling in support of the FA will be scheduled when applicable to
give HR officers every opportunity to become qualified in their FA (HR AOC for newly arriving officers and others
for departing officers).
(3) Major.
(a) All Majors in the HR AOC, BR42B officers promoted to major and other branch officers who entered the HR
AOC at the 7th year through FDB become AOC 42H and serve within the force sustainment functionally-aligned
grouping of officers. Majors will compete for promotion and schooling based on the functionally aligned categories of:
MF&E, operations support, and force sustainment. AOC 42H officers will compete in the force sustainment category.
Majors must complete ILE requirements and become JPME I certified. Majors (except 42C) should complete at least
one technical assignment as a Major to enhance their competitiveness for promotion to lieutenant colonel and to
prepare for potential Service as a CSL-selected division G–1 or battalion commander.
(b) The following are considered desired key developmental positions for majors:
1. Brigade/BCT S–1.

3. Deputy division G–1.

branch immaterial developmental assignments: USAREC battalion XO, ROTC Assistant Professor of Military Science,
USMA faculty/staff, CGSC/CAC faculty/staff, Inspector General, or multinational/coalition trainer or staff officer.
Majors must exercise continuous self-development to master fully all aspects of operations to include functional HR,
branch generalist, and Joint and multinational operations. Self-development may include correspondence courses,
civilian education, and institutional training. Officers must devote time to a professional reading program to broaden
their multi-functional, full spectrum operational perspective. As stated earlier, skills and experience will drive an
officer’s career path and future assignments. The goal of the branch is to develop an inventory of field grade officers
who embody a collective knowledge of JIIM experience. While not every officer will receive an assignment in a
qualifying Joint assignment or serve a fellowship in a JIIM agency, the goal is to provide the maximum opportunity for
HR majors to receive JIIM experience. However, this will be dependent on Army demands and position/fellowship
availability.
(4) Lieutenant colonel.
(a) Officers selected for lieutenant colonel in the force sustainment category should seek assignments of greater
responsibility in the HR AOC and branch/FA generalist positions. The HR AOC lieutenant colonel can expect
assignments in senior level staff positions and limited commands. The key education requirement for lieutenant
colonels is completion of a SSC. Officers should seek to become Joint duty qualified to enhance their competitiveness
for promotion to colonel.
(b) Lieutenant colonels should complete at least 24 months in any HR-coded position and/or complete an assignment as one of the following key and developmental positions:

band.
(c) CW4 phase should—

Drum Corps.

359

(d) CW5 phase should—
1. Complete the WOSSC not later than one year after promotion to CW5.
2. Serve as course director for the bandmaster WOBC and WOAC at the U.S. Army School of Music, or the CWO
of Army bands/proponency officer at the Adjutant General School.
c. Branch/FA generalist assignments. All HR officers will serve branch/FA generalist positions, such as instructors
and IGs, during various stages in their career. Moreover, officer branch/FA generalist assignments allow the Army the
flexibility to fill important positions from any one of the functionally aligned groupings of officers. Whenever possible,
HR officers should seek branch/FA generalist positions which fill an Army requirement while professionally developing the officer, while balancing the requirement to serve in an HR AOC-coded position for a specified period at each
grade.
d. Joint assignments. HR officers can expect to be considered for Joint duty assignments. There are Joint authorizations and Joint branch/FA generalist positions for HR officers to fill worldwide. JIIM experience is critical to the Army
and is essential to fully develop individual officers for their ability to train and equip Soldiers and grow leaders and to
provide relevant and ready land power to combatant commanders and the Joint team.
e. Nominative assignments. HR officers may be assigned to organizations and duties beyond those indicated above.
Those assignments may include; duty with special operations forces, White House Fellows, duty with the National
Security Council, the United Nations, and other international staffs, as well as HR representatives at allied Service
schools. The spectrum of possible assignments is large and these assignments can be characterized as highly responsible and important, and requiring mature, skilled, and well-grounded officers.
36–5. Assignment preferences and precedence
a. Preferences. The HR AOC has diverse assignment opportunities that allow for different career development
paths. The goal of the professional development of HR officers is to produce and sustain highly qualified, tactically and
operationally oriented officers to represent the HR community in combat and other assigned missions. Assignments in
the HR AOC will be made to develop the officer’s ability to achieve that goal. Requests from officers for assignments
that do not contribute to achieving that goal will likely be disapproved.
b. Precedence. Assignment to developmental leadership positions will have precedence, although there is flexibility
on the sequence of assignments. Typically, HR officers (except 42C) should seek assignments in the following order:
BOLC, brigade/BCT strength manager, company XO, battalion S–1/adjutant, postal platoon leader, R5 platoon leader,
casualty platoon leader, band XO (42C), CCC, battalion S–1, HR plans and operations officer/team leader, brigade,
division, corps, or ASCC/Army Staff, company/detachment command, associate bandmaster (42C), nominative assignment, ILE, brigade/BCT S–1, Sustainment brigade HR support operations officer, HR company commander, command
of a large Army band (42C) (as a major), Division G–1, MMT or TG R5 team leader, HRSC division chief, battalion
level command, SSC, Corps G–1, ASCC/Army G–1, HRSC Director, brigade-equivalent command or commanders of a
special band (42C).
36–6. Duration of critical officer life cycle assignments
a. Key HR positions. At each grade, the amount of time spent in key or critical assignments must be monitored to
ensure that officer professional development is optimized. At the rank of captain, HR officers should serve at least 24
months in any HR assignment, which may be longer in LCM BCTs. The OPMS goal for majors is to spend 3 years in
an operational assignment with 2 years spent in either a traditional or technical AOC 42H coded position. Lieutenant
colonels and colonels selected for CSL command or key billet assignment will serve 2–3 years in the selected position.
Officers selected for garrison command may have command tours up to 3 years in length.
b. HR AOC life cycle. Figure 36–1 displays the HR AOC life cycle. Additionally, it identifies branch standards and
developmental assignments that increase promotion potential.
c. HR WO life cycle. Figure 36–2 displays an HR WO life cycle model with key developmental positions that will
provide leadership opportunities and development of technical competency.
36–7. Key Active Army officer life cycle initiatives
The following section provides branch life cycle function and highlights changes associated with implementing force
stabilization initiatives and transformation.
a. Structure. HR positions are found at all echelons in TOE and TDA organizations. The Total Army Analysis
08–13 and Force Design Update 05–02 resulted in the creation of a number of new theater HR structures that include
the HRSC, the military mail terminal team (MMT), the R5 theater gateway team, HR company headquarters and R5,
Postal plans and operations teams and platoons, and casualty platoons and liaison teams. HR officers will serve in these
newly formed organizations and will be very involved in their development of supporting DOTLMPF of these
organizations. The greatest single cause of growth for HR officers is the re-coding of TOE battalion S–1 positions from
predominant MOS (of the unit) to BR42B, HR officer. This structural change is the direct result of the Army senior
leadership’s support for HR transformation and the recognition of the criticality of placing trained HR officers at the
battalion-level in support of the transformed modular Army.

360

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

b. Acquisition. Officers will continue to be accessed through USMA, ROTC, and Officer Candidate School.
Warrants will continue to be recruited form the NCO Corps. Both officer and WO accessions are based on preference,
qualifications, and needs of the Army. The branch will also remain a recipient of branch detailed officers from combat
arms branches. The near-term accession rate for BR42B lieutenants will increase to fill newly coded S–1 and brigade/
BCT strength manager positions.
c. Officer distribution. Officers will be provided assignment opportunities to develop the skills and experience base
necessary for Service at the next higher grade. The sequencing and timing of assignments are driven by Army
priorities. The GWOT, imminent contingency operations and Army transformation are currently driving forces behind
the distribution of officers. LCM of BCTs will also continue to influence officer distribution. Generally, officers
assigned to stabilized installations will be initial entry officers from BOLC. These officers will be assigned to an
installation for approximately 7 years. During this time, the officer will complete their platoon leader and lieutenant
years. Many of these officers will then proceed to the captains’ career course and return to the same installation to
complete assignments in other KD positions. The remaining officers will be reassigned to other installations for
positions in accordance with the needs of the Army. Field grade officers will be assigned to stabilized installations for
a period of time to complete a minimum of 2 years time on station with a goal of 3 years. The officers will gain
tactical and operational experience that will benefit them and the Army in their development in future positions.
(1) Life cycle units. Officers at all levels may be assigned to life cycled units (generally BCTs) and will remain in
the unit for a minimum of 3 years. The officer will complete lieutenant developmental, captain developmental, or major
developmental assignments during this time. Officers in these units have the possibility of greater than average time in
platoon leader, S–1, or major positions. Branch detail officers will remain in their detail branch until after completion
of the assignment to the BCT.
(2) Cyclic units. The majority of the installations and EAD CSS units will be managed on a cyclic manning system.
Replacements will be sent to these units and installations periodically to maintain readiness of the units. Tour lengths
and developmental positions opportunities can vary. Branch detail officers will remain on standard branch detail time
lines.
d. Deployment. Officers are expected to be well rounded, multi-skilled leaders who must remain personally and
professionally prepared to deploy worldwide at all times. Whether assigned to operational and deployable units or
training organizations, readiness is imperative to success of the mission. Officers must prepare themselves and their
Families for planned and no-notice deployments. In today’s fast-paced and uncertain operating environment, Families
must be ready for multiple deployments of unknown duration.
e. Sustainment.
(1) Promotion. Skills and experience, duty performance, and adherence to HR AOC requirements are all factors that
influence promotion. Promotion rates will be determined by Army needs/DOPMA goals.
(2) OER. The OER (DA Form 67–9) requires the rater and senior rater to recommend a functional category for all
Army competitive captains thru lieutenant colonels. When recommending a functional designation for rated officers,
rating officials will consider the whole person factors such asdemonstrated performance, educational background,
technical or unique expertise, military experience or training and personal preference of the officer. Functional category
recommendations by rater and senior raters on the OER will be an important factor taken into consideration during the
functional designation process.
(3) Evaluations. Lieutenant and captain evaluations will continue to be developmental in focus and will not include
a distribution evaluation by the senior rater (ACOM, COM, BCOM). The wording of senior rater comments is
significant in the identification of the best officers for future CSL boards.
(4) Development. Officer development will occur through a methodical sequence of progressive assignments in
operational, training and staff assignments. The goal is to professionally develop officers to expertly perform METL
related function during Joint and combined arms operations. These tasks include, but are not limited to development
and validation of doctrine, training, and equipment.
f. Separation. The officer separation process remains unchanged. The most current separation information can be
found on the AHRC Web page at https://www.hrc.army.mil/tagd/retire/retire.htm.
36–8. Human Resources area of concentration Reserve Component officers
a. General career development. RC (ARNG and USAR) officers play an important role in the mission of HR Corps.
The wartime effectiveness of HR is highly dependent upon the quality of HR AOC officers in ARNG and USAR units,
as well as the IRR. For guidance on RC officer development see chapter 7 (see fig 36–3, below).
(1) RC HR AOC officers are assigned to HR AOC positions in TOE units or TDA organizations at ARNG or
USAR commands where they perform the same functions as Active Army HR AOC officers. Their peacetime duties
will be similar to their wartime duties. However, they will also include those separate RC personnel management,
administrative, and operational reporting requirements unique to the ARNG and the USAR.
(2) RC career progression is often constrained by the geographic dispersion of units. Often there are not sufficient
positions in a geographic area to continue in HR AOC assignments. Planned rotation into progressively challenging

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

361

HR-related positions by RC commands is essential to producing the best-qualified HR officers. This includes assignments between the TPU organizations, IRR, and IMA positions. If geographic constraints are such that assignments to
HR AOC positions are not possible, officers are encouraged to seek qualification and assignments in another AOC with
requirements in the geographic region.
(3) Officers in the IRR may find assignments in RTU, IMA positions in active Army organizations, installations or
HQDA agencies, as well as tours of ADSW or annual training. Assignment in the IRR can also be used for completing
professional military education (PME).
(4) Job opportunities and assignments are the same for both male and female officers.

Figure 36–3. HR RC Developmental Model

b. Branch development opportunities. RC HR AOC development standards for commissioned officers are as
follows:
(1) Lieutenant phase (years 1 to 6). The BOLC II and III is the starting point for newly accessed HR officers. RC
officers should complete the resident BOLC by the 2d YOS. Officers should seek to serve in more than one unit
position during this phase allowing for maximum exposure to the diversified functions within an HR organization.
Officers are encouraged to actively participate in professional reading programs and continued corresponding studies.
(2) Captain phase (years 7 to 13). HR officers must complete either the resident CCC or the Adjutant General
Officers Advanced Course (AGOAC-RC). AGOAC-RC includes nonresident instruction and an ADT phase at the U.S.
Army Adjutant General School. Officers who have completed an OAC in a different branch may complete the

DA PAM 600–3 • 11 December 2007

AGOAC-RC to satisfy branch requirements. During this phase, all officers are highly encouraged to pursue a specialty
related undergraduate or graduate degree.
(3) Major phase (years 14 to 21). During this phase, officers should enroll in and complete ILE education (50
percent completion of the common core curriculum required for promotion to lieutenant colonel) and pursue a specialty
related graduate degree. HR officers should seek further development in HR AOC assignments during this phase.
(4) Lieutenant colonel phase (years 21 to 26). During this phase, officers must complete ILE and should seek PME
at the SSC level. Officers may seek assignment to senior command and staff positions.
(5) Colonel phase (years 26 to 30). Assignments during this phase should provide for maximum utilization skills in
the HR AOC.

(a) WO1 and CW2 phase should—

2. Complete an associate degree before eligibility for selection/promotion to CW3.

ARNG Army band (420C).
(b) CW3 phase should—
1. Successfully complete the military education requirements outlined in chapter 4.
2. Complete a baccalaureate degree before eligibility for selection to CW4.
3. Serve as a branch chief or personnel staff officer in a state area command or as a branch chief in the military
personnel division of a brigade, USAR regional command or training division (420A); or as commander of a small
USAR/ARNG Army band (420C).
(c) CW4 phase should—
1. Successfully complete the military education requirements outlined in chapter 4.
2. Serve as a branch chief or personnel staff officer in a State Area
3. Command or as a branch chief in the military personnel division of a USAR regional command or training
division (420A); or serve as commander of a small USAR/ARNG band, or as band coordinator in JFHQ (ARNG) or
RRSC (USAR) (420C).
(d) CW5 phase should—
1. Successfully complete the military education requirements outlined in Chapter 4.
2. Serve as branch chief or military personnel technician in a personnel group, as branch chief or personnel staff
officer in a theater personnel command, as chief, officer management division, state area command, USAR regional
command, Army G–1 policy integrator or as a personnel staff officer in either the National Guard Bureau or the Office
of the Chief, Army Reserve (420A); or as commander of a small USAR/ARNG Army band, (420C) with additional
duties as staff bands officer.
